Label: 18th Dynasty
Scope note: Includes the Amarna Period.

Label: Abbasid dynasty
Scope note: 749-1258 (AH 132-AH 923). Dynasty ruling the Muslim world as caliphs with Iraq at it's centre and Baghdad it's capital. The Abbasids derived from the family of the Prophet Muhammad's uncle al-'Abbas and the Meccan clan of Hashim. The Abbasids were influenced by older Persian traditions of divine rulership. The Abbasid revolution, while in origin an Arab movement, began on Persian soil and took advantage of discontent in the Persian lands. The shifting of the capital from Damascus under the Umayyads to Baghdad in Iraq symbolised a new eastward orientation of the caliphate with increasingly evident Persian material and cultural practives of the next centuries. The Abbasid caliphs adopted honorific titles expressing divine support for their rule. The first three centuries of Abbasid rule saw the full flowering of medieval Islamic civilisation and influences coming in from Persia and the Hellenistic and Byzantine cultures. The Abbasid ruler best known in the West is Harun al-Rashid (786-809 AH 170-193), who is associated with the stories of 1001 Nights.

Label: Achaemenid
Scope note: For material in the Lachish Collection belonging to the same period, use the term 'Persian Period'. For cuneiform tablets use Achaemenid Dynasty.

Label: Achaemenid Dynasty
Scope note: Iranian dynasty owing its origins to Teispes, son of Achaemenes. Originally kings of a territory called Anshan, subject to Median control, Persian independence was attained around 550 BC by Cyrus II (“The Great”). Cyrus conquered Babylon in 539 BC. The empire grew to control a vast territory extending from India to Egypt. The Achaemenids were brought to an end in 331 BC, following the victory of Alexander of Macedon over Darius III’s troops at the Battle of Gaugamela.

Label: Adil Shahi dynasty
Scope note: 1490-1686 (AH 895-AH 1097). Dynasty ruling in the western part of the Bahmanid Sultanate at Bijapur. The founder of the dynasty was Yusuf Khan, previously a commander and provisional governor for the Bahmanids. He proclaimed his independence in 1489 (AH 895). The capital Bijapur became a centre for learning and the arts, where Persian literature became part of the Persianisation process in the region. Bijapur was captured by the Mogul emperor Aurangzib Alamgir in 1686 (AH 1097).

Label: Afsharid dynasty
Scope note: 1736-1796 (AH 1148-AH 1210). Dynasty led by chieftain Nadir who was crowned Nadir Shah in 1736 (AH 1148).

Label: Aghlabid dynasty
Scope note: Islamic dynasty in north Africa whose first ruler was Ibrahim ibn al-Aghlab (800-812), from Khurasan in eastern Iran. This dynasty was granted the province of Ifriqiya by Harun al-Rashid (786-809) the Abbasid caliph.

Label: Ahrensburgian
Scope note: Late Glacial period in Northern Europe

Label: Akkadian
Scope note: The first king of the Akkadian Dynasty (Sargon I) united the whole of Mesopotamia under one ruler. Sargon and his descendants ruled from 2334 BC until around 2190 BC when the empire collapsed owing to invasion and rebellion. Akkadian is also a language spoken from around 2600 BC until the 1st and 2nd centuries AD. Within that period texts written between 2600 BC-2000 BC use the Old Akkadian language. The language then developed into Babylonian (2000 BC onwards) and Assyrian (2000 BC-600 BC) forms.

Label: Aksumite
Scope note: The term refers to an East African highland culture centred on its capital Aksum in the modern province of Tigray in Ethiopia. Unique among sub-Saharan African states of the period in issuing an independent coinage from the end of the 3rd century AD to the first quarter of the 7th century AD. For coins, the term 'Aksumite Kingdom' is entered in the State field in records with the term 'Askumite' in the Material Culture field.

Label: Alchon
Scope note: Hun tribe in Afghanistan and Pakistan c. 4th-5th century.

Label: Almohad dynasty
Scope note: The Almohad dynasty ruled in North Africa and Spain from AD 1130-1269.

Label: Almoravid dynasty
Scope note: 1056-1147; Morocco & Spain. Originating in religious movement among Berber nomads. Almoravid is the Spanish form of 'murabitun', meaning those dwelling in a hermitage or frontier fortress. This term was used for these warriors who wore veils over their faces against the sand and wind hence they were also known as 'al-mutalaththimun' meaning the veiled ones. The Almoravid recognised the Abbasid Caliphs as spiritual heads of Islam.

Label: Anasazi
Scope note: Southeast Utah, Southwest Colorado, Northeast Arizona, Northwest New Mexico.

Label: Ancient South Arabian
Scope note: This term is used to group together different ancient periods and spoken languages within the region of Southern Arabia which broadly corresponds to modern Yemen but overlaps into the adjoining areas of what are now Oman and Saudi Arabia.

Label: Andean
Scope note: The term refers to periods and cultures from the Peruvian Andes, both highland and coastal.

Label: Anglo-Egyptian Sudan
Scope note: The term refers to the date range 1899 to 1955.

Label: Anglo-Saxon
Scope note: In the context of archaeological material the term refers to the date range circa 5thC to later 11thC. For numismatic material use the term Anglo-Saxon rather than the Narrower Terms.

Label: Anglo-Viking
Scope note: Anglo-Viking is used in the context of numismatics only. It is defined as the period from c. AD 875-954 in which there were settlements within England under the authority of Scandinavian rulers. In this way, it applies to coins issued by Viking East Anglia (c. 880-910), Viking Northumbria (c. 895-954) and at unspecified sites within the Danelaw (c. 875-c. 930). It is not used with reference to Scandinavian imitations of Anglo-Saxon coins, or to coins of Cnut and his sons in the 11thC, since that period of Danish rule did not fundamentally affect the basic 'Anglo-Saxon' character of either culture or coinage.

Label: Anterior Le dynasty
Scope note: Vietnamese dynasty, 980-1009 state name: Dai Co Viet

Label: Anuradhapura
Scope note: Period in the medieval and primarily Buddhist history of Sri Lanka; ends with the Tamil invasion of the 10th century AD.

Label: Anyang
Scope note: circa 1300 BC-circa 1050 BC

Label: Apulian Greek
Scope note: The term refers to Greek objects produced in Apulia.

Label: Apulian local
Scope note: The term refers to objects produced by local peoples in Apulia in Italy, in an indigenous style.

Label: Aq Qoyunlu
Scope note: The Aq Qoyunlu '[those with] white sheep' were a nomadic Turkmen confederation centred on Diyar Bakr 1378-1508 (AH 780-908), who established power through marital alliances with the Byzantines in the later 14th century. They submitted to Timur (q.v.) and were rewarded with the grant of Diyar Bakr. Under Uzun Hasan (1457-1478), they extended their rule as far as Khurasan, Iraq and the Persian Gulf, but were overthrown by the Ottomans (q.v.) and Safavids (q.v.).

Label: Arab-Byzantine
Scope note: The term Arab-Byzantine is used for early Islamic coins before 696 (AH 77). These are coins that imitate Byzantine prototypes with legends sometimes in Greek or Latin, or Pahlavi or Arabic which were struck after the Byzantine model at the beginning of the first century of Islam. These coins were struck by or under Muslim authorities and show images such as the "Standing Caliph".

Label: Arab-Sasanian
Scope note: The term Arab-Sasanian covers the period circa 651-794 (AH 31-AH 178) and is used for early Islamic coins with Pahlavi and/or Arabic legends which were struck in the Sasanian fashion with the conventional Sasanian portrait on the obverse and on the reverse with a Zoroastrian fire-altar and two attendants. These coins were issued by the Arabs and Muslim authorities who governed the Sasanian provinces after the overthrow of the Sasanian empire. This coin type persisted in the eastern provinces of the caliphate for almost 200 years. The Yazdgird Era, commonly abbreviated as YE, is the first era inscribed on Tabaristan coins and on some Arab-Sasanian coins. YE1 (ie. year 1 of the Yazdgird Era) corresponds to AD 632/633, the first regnal year of the last Sasanian ruler Yazdgird III (632/3-651).

Label: Archaic Greek
Scope note: The term covers the date range: about 700BC-480BC.

Label: Archaic Period North America
Scope note: The term refers to a period ranging from approximately 8000 BC to 1000 BC.in North America.

Label: Artuqid dynasty
Scope note: c.1101-1409 (c.AH 494-AH 812). Turkic dynasty ruling in Diyar Bakr, Khartpert, Mardin and Mayyafariqin, an area strongly settled by Turkmens. The rise of the Zangids halted their expansion and in the thirteenth century they became for a while vassals of the Seljuks of Rum. They submitted to the Mongol Hulegu and the dynasty came to an end with the Timurid invasion.

Label: Assyrian
Scope note: The term is used to describe cultures and dynasties belonging to the northern portion of ancient Mesopotamia, corresponding to what is now northern Iraq.

Label: Aterian
Scope note: A stoneworking industry found in the region around the Atlas Mountains and the northern Sahara. Dates to the Middle Stone Age.

Label: Attic
Scope note: Used with Attica as Production place.

Label: Aurignacian
Scope note: Earliest phase of the Upper Palaeolithic, about 40,000 years ago.

Label: Ayutthaya Period
Scope note: Art historical period associated with the dynasty ruling in central Thailand from late 13thC to 18thC. Ends with the Burmese sack of the city of Ayutthaya in 1767.

Label: Ayyubid dynasty
Scope note: 1169-1260 (AH 564-AH 658). Dynasty of Kurdish origin whose most famous ruler was Saladin I, the founder of the Ayyubid dynasty in Damascus. He conquered Fatimid Egypt and replaced Isma'ili Shi'ism with strong orthodox Sunni religious and educational policy. The Ayyubids were continuing the policy of the Zangids in Syria and the earlier Great Seljuqs. After the death of the Ayyubid al-Kamil Nasir al-Din Muhammad in 1238 (AH 635) internal quarrels turned the Ayyubid empire into a confederation of principalities. The Mongol invasion put an end to Ayyubid rule.

Label: BMAC
Scope note: Bronze Age culture of Central Asia, dated circa 2200BC-1700BC.

Label: Babylonian
Scope note: The term is used to describe cultures and dynasties belonging to the southern portion of ancient Mesopotamia, corresponding to what is now southern Iraq.

Label: Bahmani Dynasty
Scope note: 1347-1538 (AH 748-944): Muslim state in the north Deccan (territory now divided between Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka), ruled by the Bahmani dynasty. The founder, 'Ala al-Din Bahman Shah (1347-1359), governor of Gulbarga for the Delhi Sultanate, declared independence in 1347.

Label: Bakun
Scope note: Fars, 5000BC-4000BC.

Label: Banijurid dynasty
Scope note: c.848-c.908 (c.AH 233-c.AH 295). The Banijurids, who were probably of Iranian origin, were local rulers at Balkh and Andaraba in the region of Tukharistan to the south of the middle Oxus, and also at Panjhir in the Hindu Kush. They were vassals of the Samanids.

Label: Banshan Period
Scope note: circa 2600 BC-2300 BC

Label: Begtiginid dynasty
Scope note: 1145-1233 (AH 529-AH 630). Turkish rulers controlling north-eastern Iraq and Kurdistan with a centre at Irbil, also in control of Harran in northern Syria.They arose out of the Turkish military entourage of the Zangids (q.v.).

Label: Birnirk
Scope note: 500-1000 - North Alaskan coast

Label: Boeotian
Scope note: Used with Boeotia as Production place.

Label: Bogomil
Scope note: The Bogomils were the followers of a Gnostic sect originally established in the 10th century AD in Bulgaria. From there their doctrines were spread by missionaries to some other areas of the Balkans and surrounding regions.

Label: Bosnian
Scope note: The term Bosnian as a narrower term of Ottoman dynasty refers to a specific cultural period on the fortress of Qasr Ibrim between 1550-1811 AD.

Label: British Iron Age East Anglia
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 50 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to the modern East Anglia - Norfolk, Suffolk and parts of Cambridgeshire - in which similar styled coins are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. The earliest coins were issued anonymously; later examples carry inscriptions that are assumed to be the names of local rulers. These include AESV, ALIIF SCAVO (or similar), ESVPRASTO, ECEN/ECE (if this is not a reference to the Iceni themselves) and ANTED. The ethnic or tribal identities of these issuers are unclear, but some may have belonged to the Iceni (who can perhaps be equated with the "Cenimagni" mentioned by Caesar - Caesar, De Bello Gallico, V.21).

Label: British Iron Age East Wiltshire
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 50 BC-10 BC. It refers to an area of Eastern Wiltshire in which a uniquely local style of Iron Age coinage flourished during the third quarter of the first century BC. These coins are all uninscribed and are closely related to contemporary "Western" coinage produced further to the north and west. The ethnic or tribal identities of its issuers are completely unknown.

Label: British Iron Age Kent
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 150 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to the modern county of Kent and parts of East Sussex and Greater London, in which similar styled coins are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. Probable rulers in this area include Dubnovellaunos, Sam, Vosenos, Eppillus, Solidu and Amminius. The ethnic or tribal identities of these rulers and the anonymous issuers of earlier coins remain uncertain, although many modern books label them as "Cantii" or "Cantiaci". In fact, this area may well have been fragmented before the Roman period. The term "South Eastern" is used in Hobbs' catalogue of the BM collection (1996) but is often considered confusing. R Hobbs, British Iron Age Coins in the British Museum, London (BMP) 1996.

Label: Bronze Age
Scope note: Bronze Age is a cultural term widely used from Europe to the Far East, and is subject to local regional subdivisions with their own chronologies. Examples: Britain and Ireland: c. 2150 BC - 800 BC France: c. 2150 BC - 800 BC Greece: c. 3200 BC - 1060 BC Italy: c. 2200BC - 975 BC Korea: c. 2000 BC - 500 BC Low Counties: c. 2000 BC - 800 BC Scandinavia: c. 1600 BC - 550 BC

Label: Burgundian
Scope note: In this thesaurus the term refers to Germanic people of the migration period, who established a post-Roman successor kingdom in Gaul during the 5thC to 6thC before absorption by the Merovingians (q.v.) in the AD 530s. NB. The term 'Burgundian’ is also used to refer to the Late Medieval dukes of Burgundy, who ruled a vast area of Europe. In such cases, the term 'Late Medieval' is entered as a Material Culture and 'Burgundy' (or its Narrow terms) are entered in Findspot or Production Place or . In such cases, for coin records, the State field should also be used to record 'Kingdom of Burgundy'.

Label: Burid dynasty
Scope note: 1104-1154 (AH 497-549). Damascus and southern Syria. Dynasty derived from Tughtigin, Atabeg of the Seljuq Amie of Damascus (Buri is the son of Tughtigin). They maintained their power through skilful diplomacy with the Fatamids and the Frankish Crusaders but these balancing policies were not popular with the 'Abbasid Caliphs.

Label: Butana Group
Scope note: Culture of the Butana-Gash region in Eastern Sudan.

Label: Buyid dynasty
Scope note: This Persian dynasty began as commanders in the army of the Daylamis who ruled the south-western corner of the Caspian Sea and were proud to emphasise their connections with the Sasanian dynasty. 'Ali, the eldest of three sons of Buya ('Imad al-Dawla), was in control of Isfahan at the time when Mardawij of the Ziyarid dynasty (q.v.) was murdered. He soon seized the whole of the Fars province while his brother Hasan held Jibal and Ahmad was in control of Kirman and Khuzistan. In 945 (AH 339) Ahmad entered Baghdad and for the next 110 years the Abbasids acknowledged the rule of the Buyids. 'Imad al-Dawla and his successors were Shi'ites.

Label: Byzantine
Scope note: The term refers to the successor state to the Roman empire in the eastern Mediterranean, from the foundation of Constantinople by Constantine the Great in AD 330 until its fall to the Ottoman Turks in AD 1453. The Byzantine period is often divided into three phases: the early Byzantine period from the early 4thC to the 7thC (see also the term Late Antique) which saw the losses of the key provinces of Syria and Egypt to the Arabs; the Middle Byzantine period from the 8thC to the early 13thC covering Iconoclasm and ending with the sack of Constantinople by the Fourth Crusade in 1204; the Late Byzantine period from the early 13thC to the mid-15thC, a period of geographical and political decline, but also of a flowering of the arts under the Palaeologan dynasty. See also the terms Late Roman and Medieval and its Narrow Terms.

Label: Calima
Scope note: The term refers to a region and a cultural tradition of Colombia in the Western Range of the Valle del Cauca department from 1500 BC to 1600 AD.

Label: Canh Hung reign period
Scope note: Canh Hung reign period (1740-1786).

Label: Cappadocian
Scope note: Used for cylinder seals, tablets and texts of the early 2nd millennium BC from South Central Anatolia. For other material use Old Assyrian.

Label: Cauca
Scope note: The term refers to a region and a style of Colombia in the Popayan valley and the Central Range in the Cauca department from 1000 to 1600 AD.

Label: Celtic
Scope note: This term is used in the British Museum database to refer generally to Early Medieval objects from Ireland, Scotland, Wales and Cornwall. For Iron age objects often described as Celtic, the term Early Celtic Art has been entered in the School/Style field.

Label: Chagatayid dynasty
Scope note: 1227-1363 (?) (AH 624-764). Transoxiana, Mogholistan and eastern Turkistan. Named after Chagatay, son of Chengiz. The founder of the Chagatayid khanate (dynasty) was Chagatay's grandson Alughu who seized Khwarazm, western Turkestan and Afghanstan. These territories became the nucleus of the khanate. The unity of the Chagatayids began to disintegrate with the rise of Timurlang in Transoxiana.

Label: Chalcidian
Scope note: Used with Italy as Production place.

Label: Chalcolithic
Scope note: Term used to define transitional period between Neolithic and Bronze Age, literally "Copper Stone Age", also known as Copper Age period in Europe. Soviet literature uses Aeneolithic.

Label: Chalukya
Scope note: Dynasty of north-west Deccan (ruling portions of Karnataka, Maharashtra, western Andhra Pradesh), India, 6thC AD-13thC AD, subdivided into Chalukyas of Badami (Bijapur), Gujarat, Kalyana and Vengi (Eastern Chalukyas).

Label: Chauhan dynasty
Scope note: Chauhan dynasty (fl. 8th-12th century) was first established at Sambhar, the salt lake area in the Amber (later Jaipur) district, Rajasthan. In the early 11th century Ajayaraja (q.v.) founded the city of Ajayameru (Ajmer), and in the mid twelfth century, his successor Vigraharaja (q.v.) captured Delhi from the Tomaras (q.v.) and annexed territory along the Yamuna River. In 12th century the Chauhans dominated Delhi, Ajmer and Ranthambhor. The last king, Prithviraja III (q.v.), resisted Muslim attack at Tarain in 1191, but was defeated by Muhammad ibn Sam (q.v.) in a second battle at Tarain in 1192.

Label: Cheng Wang
Scope note: 1115BC-1077BC (reign).

Label: Chengdi
Scope note: 32-7BC (reign)

Label: Chera
Scope note: Kingdom in Kerala, South India, mentioned in rock edicts of Asoka Maurya (c.273 BC-232 BC), and issuing lead and copper coins c.200 BC-200. The kingdom survived until the 15thC under a number of different dynasties as well as under the suzerainty of the more powerful Chola and Pandya kingdoms.

Label: Chimu
Scope note: The date range covered is AD 900-AD 1470. Christopher Donnan, 'Ceramics of Ancient Peru', Fowler Museum of Cultural History, University of California, Los Angeles, 1992.

Label: Chimu-Inca
Scope note: 1470-1660 This refers to the fusion of the Chimu and Inca cultures after the conquest of the Chimu by the Inca.

Label: Chincha-Atacama
Scope note: The term refers to a style form 1100 to 1350 in northern Chile.

Label: Chinese cultures, dynasties and periods
Scope note: The dynasty term is entered first, then as a second entry, the (reign) period or era term.

Label: Chiriquí
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place.

Label: Chola
Scope note: South Indian dynasty, originally based in the Kaveri delta and with a capital at Thanjavur/Tanjore. Came to prominence in the 8th century and flourished through into the 12th. Held all of the Tamil country as well as other parts of southern India. Under Rajaraja invaded Sri Lanka and Srivijaya, while under Rajendra (son of Rajaraja), invaded northern India as far as the Ganges.

Label: Christian
Scope note: The term 'Christian' is used for objects produced in any continent apart from Europe, in connection with Christian worship, e.g. chalices, crosses, prayer books, etc. In addition, the term is used specifically for objects from the Sudan to refer to the period 6thC AD to 1504 AD. For the Egyptian collections, the term 'Coptic' is used to refer to Christian artefacts from 4thC to the present day. The term 'Christian' is also used as a Broad Term.

Label: Christian Period
Scope note: The term Christian period is used specifically for Nubia and Sudan to refer to the period from 6thC AD (550) - 1504 AD. For Egypt, the term Coptic is used to refer to Christian artefacts from 4thC to the present day.

Label: Chupícuaro
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place.

Label: Chuquibamba
Scope note: This term refers to a style of textile from the highland region of Peru in the Late Horizon.

Label: Classic
Scope note: Period covering 300-900 AD in Mesoamerica.

Label: Classic Christian Period
Scope note: The term covers the period in Nubia and Sudan from AD 850-1100. It is subdivided into an earlier and a later phase designated Classic Christian Period I (AD 850-1000) and Classic Christian Period II (AD 1000-1100) respectively.

Label: Classical World
Scope note: Classical World is a broad term referring to the civilisations of the ancient Mediterranean from around 1000 BC to 400 AD, centred on the idea of a continuous development of literature, ideas and material culture originating in Aegean Greece and its overseas settlements and later adapted and modified by the Roman state from the time of the late Republic and early Empire. The term was originally defined after the Renaissance by the literary and artistic inheritance of Greece in the fifth and fourth centuries BC and Rome between the first century BC and fourth century AD, but later took on a broader meaning including history, material culture, settlement and economy within much wider chronological and geographical parameters. The term also includes cultures in close proximity to or in contact with Greeks and Romans, such as Cyprus, the non-Greek peoples of Anatolia such as Lycians and Carians, and the Villanovan, Etruscan and Italic communities of Italy. Other cultures, such as Phoenicians and Carthaginians, local peoples of Spain and North Africa (including Dynastic Egypt), Phrygians, Thracians, Scythians, Celts and the Germanic tribes tend to be included under other Top Terms in the thesaurus (Prehistoric, Levantine and Middle Eastern periods and cultures, and Historic European Periods and cultures). Chronologically, the term sometimes is extended to the earlier periods of Greek history before 1000 BC, including the Bronze Age Minoan and Mycenaean civilisations based on the idea of cultural ancestry.

Label: Colima
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place.

Label: Colonial Americas
Scope note: This refers to the post-Conquest period, considered to end with the date of independence achieved by each of the American republics.

Label: Commagenian
Scope note: Commagene was a small kingdom in southern Turkey, which began life as a tributary state of the Seleucid Empire c. 163 BC and later became an independent kingdom, before eventually being annexed by the Roman Empire in AD 72.

Label: Continental Iron Age
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced in continental Europe (separate regional terms are used for British Iron Age coins).

Label: Copper Age
Scope note: Term used to define transitional period between Neolithic and Bronze Age. See also Chalcolithic (literally "Copper Stone Age") in the Middle East. Soviet literature uses Aeneolithic. Copper Age is not a term used in Britain, Ireland or Scandinavia. For Italy: 3800BC-2200BC

Label: Copper Hoard
Scope note: The term refers to 1st millenium BC Gangetic Culture which is characterised by the production of large copper tools (perhaps not for use) as well as anthropomorphs.

Label: Coptic
Scope note: The term is used in the context of antiquities of a mainly Christian nature from Roman Egypt beginning from approximately 4thC and continuing into the Islamic Period down to the 12thC with diminishing application down to modern times.

Label: Corinthian
Scope note: Used with Corinth as Production place EXCEPT for `Corinthian' helmets.

Label: Cupisnique
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the Cupisnique valley.

Label: Cycladic
Scope note: Cycladic refers to material produced on the islands of the Cyclades during the Bronze Age. The Aegean Bronze Age is conventionally divided into Early, Middle and Late (with further subdivisions). This tripartite scheme was imposed by Arthur Evans on Minoan material, and extended to Cycladic and Helladic.

Label: Cypriot
Scope note: See also the term 'Eastern Mediterranean'.

Label: Cypro-Archaic
Scope note: 750 BC-450 BC The economic and commercial trends of the Cypro-Geometric period (q.v) culminated in a flowering of cultural activity in the Cypro-Archaic period. The numerous city-kingdoms, whose wealth and power are visible in tombs and increasingly monumental architecture (including urban fortifications), appear as vassals in the historical records of the Assyrian Empire. Pictorial art on vases develops considerably, while three-dimensional representation, in the form of stone and terracotta statues deposited in large numbers in tombs, reaches impressive levels.

Label: Cypro-Archaic I
Scope note: ca. 750 BC-600 BC

Label: Cypro-Geometric
Scope note: 1050 BC-750 BC The Cypro-Geometric period, some three hundred years in duration, is the first division of the Cypriot Iron Age. Settlements founded during the transitional LCIII period become the urban centres of the city-kingdoms into which the island is divided in historic times. Economic and cultural contacts with the Levantine world with are re-established (or become archaeologically visible) after a short period of isolation; contacts with the Aegean become apparent again somewhat later in this horizon. Important ceramic types include White Painted and Bichrome wares, which are decorated with geometric motifs and often occur in inventive shapes; slightly later, the distinctive Black-on-Red wares are developed on Cyprus, partly as a result of contact with the Levantine world; fine metalworking in bronze abounds, particularly in burials. Inscriptions point to the existence of Greek and Phoenician speakers on the island living alongside the local Cypriot population.

Label: Cypro-Geometric I
Scope note: ca. 1050 BC-950 BC

Label: Cypro-Geometric II
Scope note: ca. 950 BC-900 BC

Label: Dai Hoa reign period
Scope note: Dai Hoa reign period (1443-1453)

Label: Danishmandid dynasty
Scope note: 1104-1178 (AH 497-AH 573). Turkman dynasty originally from north-central Anatolia and Cappadocia who controlled the northerly route of Turkmen access into Asia Minor. The name comes from Persian Danishmand meaning wise, learned man, scholar. In 1174 the line in Sivas was conquered by the Seljuqs of Rum, the line in Malatya and Elbistan fell to the Seljuqs of Rum in 1178.

Label: Daunian
Scope note: Used with Italy (Southern) as Production place.

Label: Dawenkou culture
Scope note: Neolithic culture, circa 4300 BC-2400 BC.

Label: Daye
Scope note: 605-618. reign period.

Label: Diaguita
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style.

Label: Dien Ninh reign period
Scope note: Dien Ninh reign period (1454-1459)

Label: Dilmun
Scope note: Name of an ancient state based on the islands of Bahrain, Tarut and Failaka, and the neighbouring region of the eastern Arabian coast during the 3rd to 1st millennia BC.

Label: Dinh dynasty
Scope note: Vietnamese dynasty, 968-980 state name: Dai Co Viet

Label: Dogra dynasty
Scope note: Local rulers of Kashmir under Sikh suzerainty (1819-46); then rulers of the Indian Princely State of Kashmir (1846-1979). From 1846 under the British, the following rulers issued anonymous coins dated in the Vikrama era: Gulab Singh 1846-1856 (VS 1903-1913); Ranbir Singh 1857-1885 (VS 1914-1942); Pertab Singh 1885-1925 (VS 1942-1979).

Label: Dong Son Culture
Scope note: c.4th-1st centuries BC

Label: Dorset
Scope note: 1000 BC-1000 - North coast of Canada to Greenland

Label: Dulafid dynasty
Scope note: 840-897 (AH 225-AH 284). Arab governors appointed by the 'Abbasid Caliph Harun al-Rashid to rule the Jibal (ancient Media) in central and western Iran. The centre of power was at Karaj.

Label: Duptala
Scope note: Dynasty ruling in Kashmir c. AD 855-939.

Label: Dvaravati
Scope note: The term refers to a period of Mon culture (1st millennium AD) in central Thailand and in southern Burma.

Label: Early Anglo-Saxon
Scope note: In the context of archaeological material the term refers to the date range circa 5thC to mid-7thC. For numismatic material use the Broad Term Anglo-Saxon.

Label: Early Bronze Age
Scope note: Early Bronze Age is a cultural term widely used from Europe to the Far East, and is subject to local regional subdivisions with their own chronologies. Britain and Ireland: c. 2150 BC - 1600 BC France: c. 2150 BC - 1600 BC Italy: c. 2200 BC - 1600 BC Low Countries: c. 2000 BC - 1800 BC Greece: The terms ' Early Cycladic', 'Early Minoan' and 'Early Helladic' are recorded for objects described as 'Early Bronze Age'.

Label: Early Christian Period
Scope note: The term covers the period in Nubia and Sudan from AD 550-850. It is subdivided into an earlier and a later phase designated Early Christian Period I (AD 550-700) and Early Christian Period II (AD 700-850) respectively.

Label: Early Christian Period I
Scope note: The term covers the period in Nubia and Sudan from AD 550-700.

Label: Early Christian Period II
Scope note: The term covers the period in Nubia and Sudan from AD 700-850.

Label: Early Corinthian
Scope note: According to Amyx’s chronology (1988, p. 428), based on Payne’s chronology and modified by Hopper, Dunbabin, and Coldstream, the Early Corinthian period extends from 620/615 to 595/590 BC.

Label: Early Cycladic
Scope note: The Early Cycladic period (3200BC – 2000BC) refers to material produced in the Cyclades during the Aegean Early Bronze Age. Although it is part of the tripartite scheme (Early, Middle and Late) into which the Aegean Bronze Age is conventionally divided, it is difficult to apply the same subdivisions (I,II,III) as for Early Minoan or Early Helladic. For this reason it is divided into partly overlapping cultural groups, initially defined by Colin Renfrew. The three main groups used to subdivide the period are Grotta-Pelos (q.v.), Keros-Syros (q.v.) and Phylakopi I (q.v.).

Label: Early Cypriot
Scope note: ca. 2400/2300 BC-2000/1900 BC The first division of the Cypriot Bronze Age, characterised by the use of Red Polished pottery, simple bronze tools and burials in chamber tombs usually placed outside the settlement areas. The beginning of the period overlaps with the Late Chalcolithic in some part of Cyprus, especially the west of the island, and with the Philia culture which has links with contemporary Anatolia (not represented in the BM collection).

Label: Early Dynastic I
Scope note: A term used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia between approximately 2900-2700 BC.

Label: Early Dynastic II
Scope note: A term used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia between approximately 2700-2600 BC; it has been questioned whether Early Dynastic II material culture can really be distinguished from that of the preceding Early Dynastic I.

Label: Early Dynastic III
Scope note: A term used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia between approximately 2600 BC and the establishment of the Akkadian empire around 2300 BC.

Label: Early Dynastic Middle East
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia in the period approximately 2900 BC-2350 BC.

Label: Early Haftavan Period VIB
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.1900BC-1550BC.

Label: Early Historic
Scope note: The term is used to broadly define the period in India between about 500 BC - AD 500 and follows the Iron Age. It includes the periods of the Mauryan empire and the Guptas.

Label: Early Iron Age
Scope note: For Italy: Early Iron Age early c. 1000 BC to 880 BC Early Iron Age late c. 900 BC to 780 BC

Label: Early Islamic
Scope note: Term used to describe material culture generally dating between the 7thC-10thC. See also 'Late Antique'.

Label: Early Medieval
Scope note: For the British Isles, the term refers to the period from about AD 400 to about AD 1050. The term 'Celtic' is used to refer generally to Early Medieval objects from Ireland, Scotland, Wales and Cornwall, ie. the non-Anglo-Saxon areas. For Continental Europe, for the western territories of the former Roman Empire (Italy, France, Spain, etc.) the Early Medieval period is generally accepted to begin in around AD 400. For the eastern Roman Empire, the term Byzantine is used. N.B. For all European coins, the term 'Medieval' (rather than the Narrow Terms 'Early Medieval' and 'Late Medieval') is used as a general term for the period c. 400 to c. 1500. Other term can also be entered, such as 'Burgundian'.

Label: Early Proto-Attic
Scope note: Used with Attica as Production place.

Label: Early Quimbaya
Scope note: The term refers to a cultural period and style of the Quimbaya region of Colombia in the Middle Cauca valley and the Central Range in the Antioquia, Caldas, Risaralda and Quindio departments from 500 BC to 600 AD.

Label: Early Sasanian
Scope note: 3rdC-4thC AD. This term has not been used for coins (see under Sasanian).

Label: Early Tolima
Scope note: The term refers to a cultural period and a style in the Tolima region of Colombia in the Magdalena valley in the Tolima and Huila departments from 1 AD to 900 AD.

Label: Early Uruk
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia dating to between 4000-3500 BC.

Label: East Asian cultures, dynasties and periods
East Greek
Scope note: The term is used for objects produced in the East Greek islands or the West coast of Asia Minor. For more specific regional East Greek material, e.g. Chiot (Chian), search also under the individual places of production, e.g. made in Chios.

Label: East Greek Archaic I
Scope note: The term refers to a chronological classification system according to Kerschner-Schlotzhauer 2005. The terms 'East Greek Archaic I' and 'East Greek Archaic II', and any of their Narrow Terms, should be entered in addition to the East Greek regional subdivisions Narrow terms: Aeolian, Chiot, East Dorian, Ionian (North Ionian or South Ionian) or Rhodian.

Label: Eastern British Iron Age
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 80 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Essex and Hertfordshire, parts of Kent, Suffolk, Cambridgeshire, Bedfordshire, Northamptonshire, Berkshire, Buckinghamshire and Oxfordshire, in which similar styled coinages are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. Notable rulers in this area include Addedomaros, Dubnovellaunos, Tasciovanus, Dias, Rues and Cunobelin. The ethnic or tribal identities of these rulers and the anonymous issuers of earlier coins remain unclear, but some may have belonged to the Trinovantes or the Catuvellauni. Both are known from Roman sources describing the administrative structure of the later Roman province, but only the former definitely pre-dated the Roman invasion of AD 43. The term "Northern" was used by Hobbs in the BM catalogue (1996) but is often considered confusing. J Creighton, Coins and Power in Iron Age Britain, Cambridge (CUP) 2000. R Hobbs, British Iron Age Coins in the British Museum, London (BMP) 1996.

Label: Eastern Ganga
Scope note: Term associated with a dynasty based in southern Andhra Pradesh.

Label: Eastern Ganga Dynasty
Scope note: The Eastern Ganga Dynasty (c. 1078-1434) ruled parts of Orissa and West Bengal.

Label: Eastern Han dynasty
Scope note: 23-220. In some sources, 25-220.

Label: Eastern Mediterranean
Scope note: The term is used by the Greek and Roman Department for objects with multiple centres of production along the Mediterranean coastline from the Aegean to Egypt. It reflects the broad cultural connections between regions at certain periods, particularly the 'International Style' c. 1400 BC-1200 BC. For this reason it is usually for objects from Bronze Age Cypriot sites: after this period, centres of production are better defined. The term is not used for Hellenistic (q.v.) or Roman (q.v.) objects. See also the Place term 'Mediterranean' with Comment 'East Mediterranean' for objects described as 'East Mediterranean' in the records for the Prehistory and Europe Department. See also the term 'Cypriot' and its Narrow Terms.

Label: Eburran
Scope note: Period of the Later Stone Age of East Africa, particularly the Lake Nakuru - Naivasha Basin region, characterised by large backed blades, crescents, edge retouched flakes and burins mostly made from obsidian. The Eburran dates from c.13,000-8000 and is divided into 5 phases the earliest of which are pre-Neolithic and the last, phase 5, Neolithic including pottery and bones of domesticated animals. Formerly referred to as Aurignacian by Leakey at Gamble's Cave this term has also replaced Kenya Capsian.

Label: Edo Period
Scope note: 1603-1868 N.B. The Edo period is routinely said to start in 1600, 1603 or 1615, depending on its definition, but the date used here is 1603.

Label: Egypt, Sudan and Nubia periods and cultures
Scope note: The term covers all periods, kingdoms, dynasties and cultures from Egypt and from Sudan, including those of Egyptian and Sudanese Nubia.

Label: Elamite
Scope note: Term not used in its own right, instead see narrower terms. Term used to describe the period and material culture of south-western Iran between circa 3000-539 BC which was referred to as the land of Elam in ancient Mesopotamian sources. Elamite is also an ancient language spoken in this region at that time.

Label: Epi-palaeolithic
Scope note: Term used in Africa, Middle East and parts of Europe for assemblages of the early recent or Holocene period, after the end of the last Ice Age and before the beginning of farming, approximately 12,000-6,000BC. These assemblages were used by hunter-gatherers and show few changes in content or technology from the preceding Upper Palaeolithic period except in the greater numbers of backed blades, crescents and microliths. This similarity gives rise to the term epi (like)-palaeolithic. In northern Europe, environmental change was much greater at the end of the Ice Age, human adaptations changed in response and, consequently, the stone artefact assemblages are much different from those of the Upper Palaeolithic and are distinguished as Mesolithic. Despite this distinction the terms Epi-palaeolithic and Mesolithic are occasionally used as if synonymous.

Label: Erligang
Scope note: 15thC BC-13thC BC

Label: Etruscan
Scope note: Used with Italy as Production place.

Label: Etrusco-Campanian
Scope note: Used with either Campania or Etruria as Production place.

Label: Etrusco-Latin
Scope note: Used with either Latium or Etruria as Production place.

Label: Euboean
Scope note: Used with Euboea as Production Place.

Label: Faiyum Culture
Scope note: Middle Egyptian culture contemporary with Badarian culture in Upper Egypt.

Label: Faliscan
Scope note: Used with Faliscan Territory as Production place.

Label: Fara
Scope note: Used for tablets of the later Early Dynastic period in Mesopotamia.

Label: Fatimid dynasty
Scope note: 909-1171 (AH 297-AH 555). Rulers of North Africa, then Egypt and southern Syria who claimed title of caliph. They claimed descent from Fatima the daughter of the Prophet Mohammad and wife of the fourth Caliph 'Ali. In 909 (AH 297) the Mahdi was proclaimed caliph in rivalry to the 'Abbasids of Baghdad. From Egypt the Fatimids extended into Palestine and Syria and reached the zenith of their power in the 11th century.

Label: Fauresmith
Scope note: 'The most recent phase of the Early Stone Age, dating to around 200,000 years ago, recognised on the central plateau of South Africa. The Fauresmith is characterised by small pointed handaxes, as well as the use of lydianite (indurated shale) as a raw material.

Label: Filali Sharifs
Scope note: The Filali Sharifs claimed descent from the Prophet Muhammad. They orignated from south-eastern Morocco and restored central authority throughout Morocco in the late 17th-18th centuries.

Label: Final Bronze Age
Scope note: Italy: c. 1200 BC - 975 BC

Label: Gallinazo
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style.

Label: Gallo-Roman
Scope note: Used with Gaul as Production place.

Label: Gallo-Visigothic
Scope note: The term refers to the period of the Visigoths in Southern France from the time of the establishment of the Kingdom of Toulouse in AD 414 until the expulsion of the Visigoths by Clovis in AD 507.

Label: Gandhara
Scope note: A Buddhist culture situated between the lower Kabul Valley in present-day Afghanistan and the Indus river in Pakistan

Label: Gaochang kingdom
Scope note: Central Asian kingdom.

Label: Gaudo
Scope note: 3000BC-2000BC Used with Campania as production place.

Label: Gentle
Scope note: The term has been recorded in connection with objects excavated or collected by John Eric Sidney Thompson.

Label: Geometric Greek
Scope note: About 900-700 BC.

Label: Geometric Kebaran
Scope note: Epi-Palaeolithic culture of the late Pleistocene in the Levant characterised by geometric microliths and dating from 15,500BC to c.12,900BC.

Label: Germanic
Scope note: The term applies to a group of peoples living in the region of Europe outside the Roman Empire known in classical sources as Germania, from around the 1st century BC - 8th century AD. During the Migration Period (around the late 4th-6th centuries AD) a number of them crossed the Rivers Rhine and Danube to settle within the former borders of the Empire.

Label: Ghaznavid dynasty
Scope note: 977-1186 (AH 366-AH 582). Khurasan, Afghanistan, northern India. Rulers played main part in expansion of Islam into India. With the adoption of Persian administrative and cultural ways the Ghaznavid abandoned their original Turkish steppe background and became largely integrated with the Perso-Islamic tradition. Under Mas'ud I, the son of Mahmud I, the Ghaznavid empire could not be maintained in the west against the Seljuqs, and Khwarazm, Khurasan and northern Persia were lost. The rise of the Ghurids reduced the power of the Ghaznavids and the dynasty was extinguished in 1186 (AH 582).

Label: Ghurid dynasty
Scope note: Ruled circa 1000-1215 in Khurasan, Afghanistan and Northern India.

Label: Golaseccan
Scope note: Used with Italy (Northern) as Production place.

Label: Graeco-Iberian
Scope note: This term refers to the Greek colonies established at Emporion and Rhode in the 6thC BC which flourished until the Roman conquest of Spain in the late 3rdC BC-early 2ndC BC. It also refers to the indigenous cultures of Spain, or Iberians, contemporary to the aformentioned colonies. This includes the coinage minted by those settlements in the vicinity of Emporion and Rhode and also those minted by those colonies themselves.

Label: Graeco-Roman
Scope note: This term is only used by the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan to include both Hellenistic Egypt from 332 BC to 30 BC and Roman Egypt from 30 BC to around AD 400 (later Roman material in Egypt down to AD 641 usually being placed under Roman Period or Coptic). It is an imprecise term for material from Ptolemaic or Roman Egypt which has not yet been ascribed more accurately to one or the other. See also the terms 'Greek' and 'Roman'.

Label: Greco-Bactrian
Scope note: The term refers to a Greek kingdom (c. 250-145 BC) in Bactria (Afghanistan north of the Hindu Kush) and Sogdiana (the Central Asian Amu Darya region of Uzbekistan and Tajikistan). The region was originally part of the Seleucid empire, but the Bactrian governor Diodotus gained independence in c. 250 BC. Sogdiana broke away in turn from Bactria c. 200 BC; the rest of the region was lost to nomadic tribes of the Indo-Scythians and Yuezhi by c. 145 BC.

Label: Greek
Scope note: The term refers to 'Greek culture', ie. objects produced throughout all periods from the Aegean (or Greek) Neolithic to the Hellenistic periods. See also the term 'Graeco-Roman'.

Label: Grotta-Pelos Culture
Scope note: The earliest of the three cultural groups into which the Early Cycladic (q.v.) period is divided, based on consistently recurring types of pottery, bronze and marble objects. The name refers to the type sites used by Colin Renfrew to define the culture, although the term applies to material from the Cyclades as a whole. There are not always clear boundaries between cultural groups, but an approximate date range is 3200BC – 2800BC.

Label: Guetar
Scope note: It has not been possible to identify this term in the literature.

Label: Gupta
Scope note: Dynasty ruling most of central and north India c. AD 319/20-535. The first king Chandragupta I established a Gupta era which remained in use in central India and Nepal until the thirteenth century. The period of the Gupta empire is considered the Classical age of Hindu civilisation in India.

Label: Gurjara-Pratihara
Scope note: Dynasty that ruled much of northern India from the 6th to the 11th century. There were two branches of the dynasty: that of Harichandra ruled in Mandor, Marwar (Jodhpur, Rajasthan), in the 6th-9th century; that of Nagabhata ruled first at Ujjain and later at Kanauj in the 8th-11th century.

Label: Gurkha dynasty
Scope note: Kingdom in the hills of Nepal, north-west of Kathmandu, which first minted coins in AD 1749 under the ruler Prithvi Narayan Shah (1742-1775). He conquered the Kathmandu valley in 1768, moved his capital to Kathmandu and established the Shah dynasty. He attacked Sikkim in 1789, then Tibet in 1790. Further territorial expansion southwards brought the kingdom into conflict with the British. Following the treaty of Sagauli in 1815, a British Resident was installed in Kathmandu. Men from this region are still recruited into the elite Gorkha regiment of the British army.

Label: Hadrami
Scope note: Refers to the kingdom of Hadramaut (capital at Shabwa). The largest kingdom in South Arabia occupying the eastern part of the peninsula from the 7th century BC - 3rd century AD.

Label: Haftavan Period IC-IA
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c200-600 AD.

Label: Haftavan Period II
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.539BC-331BC.

Label: Haftavan Period III
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.800BC-700BC.

Label: Haftavan Period IV
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.1100BC-800BC.

Label: Haftavan Period V
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.1450BC-1100BC.

Label: Haftavan Period VIB
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.1900BC-1450BC.

Label: Haftavan Period VIC
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.2200BC-2000BC.

Label: Haftavan Period VII
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.2600BC-2200BC.

Label: Haftavan Period VIII
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.2600BC.

Label: Hagiz Group
Scope note: Culture identified in the Butana region in Eastern Sudan.

Label: Hallstatt A
Scope note: Europe; 1200-1125 BC

Label: Hallstatt B
Scope note: Europe; 1125-800 BC

Label: Hallstatt C
Scope note: Europe; 800-600 BC

Label: Hallstatt D
Scope note: Europe; 600-450 BC

Label: Ham Nghi
Scope note: (1885) reign.

Label: Hampshire
Scope note: The term has been recorded in connection with objects excavated or collected by John Eric Sidney Thompson.

Label: Hassuna
Scope note: Prehistoric period, pottery type and cultural term; 7000BC-6000BC.

Label: Heisei Era
Scope note: 1989-onwards

Label: Hellenistic
Scope note: 323 BC-31 BC. Do not use for cuneiform tablets (instead use Macedonian Dynasty, Seleucid or Late Babylonian for anything without a specific date). Ptolemaic is frequently used by G&R for Hellenistic terracottas made in Egypt.

Label: Hephthalite
Scope note: The Hephthalites, also known as the White Huns, were a group of Central Asian nomads who migrated from the Altai region to Transoxiana around AD 420-440, driving out the Kushans (q.v.). After defeat and being made tributary in turn by the Turks in 553 (q.v. 'Turkic'), some Hephthalites may have joined the Avars (q.v.) in their migration to the steppes and Central Europe.

Label: Hiberno-Norse
Scope note: The term is restricted to numismatics. There is a tendency to use 'Hiberno-Viking' to describe material down to the late 10thC and 'Hiberno-Norse' from the late 10thC onwards, including the coinage introduced in the 990s, which is always referred to in this way. Both apply to material produced in Ireland. There is no corresponding term in general usage for Scottish material.

Label: Himyarite
Scope note: Refers to the kingdom of Himyar (capital at Zafar). In the 1st century AD the kingdom controlled large parts of Yemen and Saudi Arabia (at its height as far north as Riyadh).

Label: Hispano-Visigothic
Scope note: The term refers to the period of the settlement of the Visigoths in Iberia from AD 507, following their expulsion from most of Gaul. The Kindom of Toledo, which they formed, lasted until the Islamic conquest in AD 711.

Label: Hissar III
Scope note: Period based on the excavated sequence at this site in north-east Iran and corresponding to an approximate date of c. 2500-1700 BC, or the Middle Bronze Age in this region.

Label: Hittite
Scope note: Between 1400 and 1200 BC the Hittites established one of the great empires of the ancient Middle East. At its height, the empire (also called the New Kingdom) encompassed central Turkey, north western Syria, and Upper Mesopotamia (north eastern Syria and northern Iraq). By 1300 the Hittite Empire bordered on Egypt and both powers vied for control of wealthy cities on the Mediterranean coast. This led to the Battle of Kadesh with Rameses II (1274 BC).

Label: Hohokam
Scope note: 400-1450 Central to Southern Arizona

Label: Hongshan culture
Scope note: Neolithic culture, circa 4500 BC-3000 BC.

Label: Hongwu
Scope note: 1368-1398 (reign) Emperor Taizu (Zhu Yuanzhang).

Label: Hopewell
Scope note: Hopewell is a cultural designation relating to a people who build mounds and have a material culture active in the Ohio, Illinois, Missouri, Mississippi Valley region of the United States. 200BC - 400AD (though recently some scholars have pushed the Ohio Hopewell back to 0 - 400AD)

Label: Hun
Scope note: Nomadic tribes from north-eastern Asia who invaded and settled in Afghanistan and northern India (4th-7th centuries). The principal tribes appear to be the Kidarites, Alchon, Nezak and Hephthalites

Label: Hung Tri reign period
Scope note: The Hung Tri reign period (1588-1591) of the ruler Mac Mau Hop of the Mac Dynasty (1527-1592) of Vietnam.

Label: Hyde
Scope note: The term has been recorded in connection with objects excavated or collected by John Eric Sidney Thompson.

Label: Ibero-Punic
Scope note: This term refers to the indigenous cultures of Spain often referred to as Iberian. These were contemporary to both the Greek and Carthaginian colonies established in Spain from the 6thC BC, whilst influenced by both groups, the Iberians were also distinct cultural group and minted their own coinage. This term refers to the coins minted by both the Carthaginian settlements in Spain and also those minted by the Iberian settlements.

Label: Ica
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the Ica Valley.

Label: Ice Age
Scope note: The Ice Age refers to the period between 2.6 million and 11,700 years ago during which climate varied through alternating warm and cold periods. Modern humans and many other mammal species evolved during this period. During some cold stages (glaciations) temperatures dropped so much that continental and alpine ice sheets spread over vast areas. With water frozen to ice, sea levels also dropped providing humans and animals with opportunities to spread out across land bridges which were then submerged again during warm periods such as we live in today. Throughout the Ice Age, Britain formed part of mainland of Europe. However, 'Ice Age' (as used in the British Museum records) is a term in popular use for the period of warm and cold phases between 126,000 and 11,000 years ago or, more narrowly, to the time after 40,000 years ago when fully modern humans arrived in Europe and North America. The Pleistocene is a geological term used to refer to the same period of climatic changes as the Ice Age. The Last Ice Age refers to the period of warm and cold phases between 126,000 and c.11, 000 years ago when fully modern people like us (Homo sapiens sapiens) spread around the earth.

Label: Idrisid dynasty
Scope note: 789-926 (AH 172-AH 375). The first dynasty to introduce the doctrines of Shi'ism into the region of Morocco. Idris I was a great-grandson of Imam Hasan and therefore a direct descendant of the Prophet Mohammad and his son-in-law 'Ali ibn 'Ali Talib.

Label: Ilkhanid dynasty
Scope note: 1256-1353 (AH 654-AH 754). The Mongol Il-Khanids were rulers of the regions of Persia, Iraq, Transcaucasia and Anatolia. Hulegu (Huluku), son of Toluy, adopted the title of Il-Khan meaning territorial Khan and subordinate to the Great Khan. The capitals of the Il-Khanid's of Persia were Tabriz and Maragha in the north-west, and later at Sultaniyya near Qazwin.

Label: Indo-Greek
Scope note: The term refers to a specific independent Greek kingdom (c.180 BC-AD 10), ruling in Afghanistan south of the Hindu Kush mountains and north-western Pakistan up to the Indus and Sutlej rivers (i.e. including the Punjab). The Indo-Greeks lost Afghanistan and most of Pakistan to Indo-Scythians c. 70 BC, but survived in the Punjab until c. AD 10. They are the successors to the Greco-Bactrians, who broke away from the Seleucid empire c. 250 BC to form an independent Greek kingdom in Bactria (Afghanistan north of the Hindu Kush) and Sogdiana (modern Tajikistan), which was lost to nomadic tribes of the Indo-Scythians and Yuezhi by c. 100 BC.

Label: Indo-Parthian
Scope note: The term refers to a culture from c. 1stC to 3rdC AD. Knowledge of the so-called Indo-Parthians derives largely from coins and a few inscriptions. Some of the names and coin designs suggest links with the Parthians of Iran, but the precise relationship is not clear. In the first century AD the Indo-Parthians seem to have gained control of the region stretching from the Punjab, Sind and Gandhara (north-west Pakistan) to Seistan (south-east Iran). The principal ruler is Gondophares (c. AD 32–60). The title ‘Gondophares’ (Old Persian Vindapharna ‘Winner of Glory’) was adopted by his successors in addition to their given names on coins from Arachosia (Qandahar) and the Punjab. However, in Sind and Seistan they also issued coins in their own right as ‘king’ or ‘king of kings’. This suggests a complex situation of rulers and sub-rulers who owed varying degrees of allegiance to the Indo-Parthian king.

Label: Indo-Scythian
Scope note: Dynasty of Central Asian nomadic origin, who ruled in south-east Afghanistan and north-west Pakistan circa 75 BC-AD 64.

Label: Indus Civilisation
Scope note: Urban civilisation based in the northwestern part of the Indian subcontinent, today in Pakistan and western India. Developing out of earlier prehistoric cultures, it flourished over a very wide area between approximately 2,500 and 2,000 BC. Script was known but is undeciphered today, not least as surviving inscriptions (mostly on seals) are no more than about a dozen characters. Major settlements, such as Mohenjo-daro and Harappa, were laid out on a grid pattern with drainage and were clearly organised by a central power. The earliest fragments of woven cotton from the subcontinent come from these sites. Trade with sites in the Persian Gulf, as well as with settlements on the Oxus, has been substantiated.

Label: Inju dynasty
Scope note: Dynasty ruling Shiraz from c. 1336-1356.

Label: Integration Period
Scope note: The term refers to a cultural period applied to Ecuador.

Label: Ionic
Scope note: This term is being checked against the object records.

Label: Iranian periods and cultures
Scope note: Iranian periods and cultures encompasses a wide range of periods, dynasties and languages from prehistory to the present and at times including areas beyond the modern political borders of Iran.

Label: Iron Age
Scope note: Iron Age is a cultural term widely used from Europe to the Far East, and is subject to local regional subdivisions with their own chronologies. Examples: India: c. 1000 BC - 400 BC (later in the South). For Iron Age objects often described as Celtic, the term Early Celtic Art has been entered in the School/Style field.

Label: Iron Age I
Scope note: Levant: 1150BC-950BC. Iran: 1450BC-1100BC.

Label: Iron Age II
Scope note: Levant, Iron Age IIA: 950BC-722BC. Levant, Iron Age IIB: 722BC-586BC. Iran: 1100BC-800BC.

Label: Iron Age III
Scope note: Levant: 586BC-332BC. Iran: 800BC-500BC.

Label: Iron Age/Romano-British
Scope note: 'Iron Age/Romano-British' is used where it is not possible to assign an object definitively to the Late Iron Age or Romano-British periods. This is particularly the case for incomplete or undiagnostic objects and objects used in both periods. Many of the objects in this category are from sites spanning both periods.

Label: Isin-Larsa
Scope note: The term is used to describe the period approximately 2000 BC-1800 BC when southern Mesopotamia was dominated by the cities Isin and Larsa.

Label: Ispahbads
Scope note: The Dabuyid Ispahbads were local princes who rose to power in the south western Caspian highlands of Gilan in the late Sasanian period. They gradually moved eastwards and controlled Tabaristan in the south eastern corner of the Caspian lands. Arab raids into this area started under the caliphate of 'Uthman. The dynasty of the Dabuyids, who were Zoroastrians, ended in 758 (AH 141).

Label: Italic
Scope note: Used for objects produced in parts of Italy outside of Roman rule.

Label: Italo-Corinthian
Scope note: Used with Italy or narrower terms as Production place.

Label: Jalisco
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place.

Label: Jemdet Nasr
Scope note: Jemdet Nasr is the name of a site located in modern Iraq to the south of Baghdad. The name is applied to a culture based on excavations at the site that have produced a distinct assemblage of objects (c.3000BC-2900BC). The assemblage is restricted to the neighbouring region.

Label: Jidle III
Scope note: Term referring to material from level III at Tell Jidle as excavated by M.E.L. Mallowan, and dating to ca 1700-1600 BC.

Label: Jomon Period
Scope note: To 200 BC

Label: Jorwe Culture
Scope note: Prehistoric culture found in western India, in the region of the modern state of Maharashtra. Named after the type site. 2nd millennium BC.

Label: Judaean
Scope note: The term is used in relation to objects produced in ancient Judaea under the Hasmonean (c. 170BC-37BC) and Herodian (37BC-95AD) dynasties and during the two Jewish revolts (The Jewish War 66AD-68AD and The Bar Kochba Revolt 132AD-135AD). From 301-201BC most of ancient Judaea was under Ptolemaic control; it was then under the Seleucids under Antiochus III Megas. By 40BC Judaea was almost entirely dominated by Rome, and the first king of the Herodian dynasty, Herod I, was appointed by a declaration of the Roman Senate. Coins minted under the Roman Prefects of Judaea ('the Procurators') have the period culture 'Roman Provincial', as do the later imperial coins minted in Judaean cities (e.g. Aelia Capitolina, the new Roman Jerusalem). The term is not used for the collections in the Department of Greek and Roman. If the object dates to the period before Judaea became a Roman province (about 6AD) the term 'Hellenistic' is used, and if after Rome takes over then the term 'Roman' is used.

Label: Kadamba dynasty
Scope note: 345-525. Ancient royal family of Karnataka that ruled from Banavasi in present day Uttara Kannada district. The dynasty later continued to rule as a feudatory of larger Kannada empires, the Chalukya and the Rashtrakuta empires for over five hundred years during which time they branched into Goa and Hanagal. At the peak of their power under King Kakushtavarma, they ruled large parts of Karnataka.

Label: Kaftari
Scope note: Fars, 2200BC-1600BC.

Label: Kakwayhid dynasty
Scope note: 1008-1051 (AH 398-AH 443). Petty Kurdish and Daylami dynasty of the Zagros region when the power of the Buyids (q.v.) began to fade. With the rise of the Seljuqs in Persia the Kakwayhid's lost their independence and were reduced to vasaledge. Muhammad known as Ibn Kakuya, who was the son of Dushmanziyar, was the governor of Isfahan in 1008 (AH 398). He soon expanded his power to Hamadan and Kurdistan and his court circle included the philosopher and physian Ibn Sina (Avicenna) who functioned as his vizier.

Label: Kalachuri dynasty
Scope note: The Kalachuris who ruled from Ratanpur from the early 11th century were distantly related to, and feudatories of, the Tripuri Kalachuris. They gained prominence under Jajalladeva I in the early 12th century. Early historical documents of their rule continue to Pratapamalla (reigned c. 1188-1217) and are then interrupted until the 15th century, by which time the family had split into two branches based at Ratanpur and Raipur. No authentic historical document relating to their history after the 15th century is known.

Label: Kandyan
Scope note: A period named after the city Kandy, in central upland Sri Lanka, the capital of the last indigenous kingdom of the pre-colonial period (18th-19th century).

Label: Karkota
Scope note: Dynasty ruling in Kashmir c. AD 520-855.

Label: Karts of Herat
Scope note: The Karts or Kurts of eastern Khurasan and northern Afghanistan were an indiginous dynasty who claimed to be heirs of the Ghurids. The Mongols allowed Shams al-Din I Muhammad (1245-1277, AH 643-676) to rule as a vassal prince in Herat and the mountains of Ghur. They remained loyal allies of the Il-Khans of Persia.

Label: Kassite
Scope note: With the collapse of strong control at Babylon around 1600 BC, a dynasty of Kassite kings, whose original homeland may have been in the mountains to the east, was able to claim the throne and eventually united the cities of southern Mesopotamia into a single country, Babylonia. The last Kassite king was defeated by the Elamites of southwest Iran in 1155 BC.

Label: Kebaran
Scope note: The earliest of the late Pleistocene Epi-Palaeolithic cultures of the Levant which are transitional between the Upper Palaeolithic and Neolithic dating from c.20,500BC to 17,500BC.

Label: Keros-Syros Culture
Scope note: The second of the three cultural groups into which the Early Cycladic (q.v.) period is divided, based on consistently recurring types of pottery, bronze and marble objects. The name refers to the islands used by Colin Renfrew to define the culture, although the term applies to material from the Cyclades as a whole. There are not always clear boundaries between cultural groups, but an approximate date range is 2800BC – 2300BC.

Label: Khalji dynasty
Scope note: Rulers of the Delhi Sultanate 1296-1320.

Label: Khans of Ganja
Scope note: Also known as the Ganja khanate, under the dominion of Iran in 1747-1805 (AH 1160-AH 1220).

Label: Khans of Kirman
Scope note: The Kutlugh Khans of Kirman were established by Burak Hajib during the years when Mongol suzeranity over Iran was being consolidated by Ghengiz Khan. He and his successors were vassals of the Mongols who superseded them in AH 703.

Label: Khmer
Scope note: Cambodia

Label: Khwarazm Shahs
Scope note: 995-1231 (AH 385-AH 628). Khwarazm is the classical Chorasmia, the rich and well irrigated region on the lower Oxus. In later times it was known as the Khanate of Khiva. It may have been an early home of the Iranians. Khwarazm was under Samanid rule until it was added to the Ghaznavid empire under Mahmud in 1017 (AH 408). After the middle of the 11th century Khwarazm was under Seljuq rule. Since the time of Malik Shah the hereditary governors of Khwarazm received the title of Khwarazm Shah. After the conquest of Transoxiana by Genghis Khan in 1220 (AH 617) Khwarazm came first under the rule of Mongols and then Turkish Central Asian steppe peoples.

Label: Kidarite
Scope note: The Kidarites are thought to have been Huns who possibly acted as mercenaries for the Sasanians; they subsenquently took territory in Bactria and Gandhara from the Kushans and Sasanians, late 4thC. AD - but the name derives from use of 'Kidara' on coinage. They began to issue their own coins in the style of both Kushan and Sasanian issues, and are only known from coinage.

Label: Kien Phuc
Scope note: (1884) reign.

Label: Koban
Scope note: The Koban culture is based in the central Caucasus. Koban articles are diverse, but the most typical are bronze items of the 11th to 4th centuries BC.

Label: Kofun Period
Scope note: 250-552 - Tumulus

Label: Kuninda dynasty
Scope note: An ancient political unit of India which issued coins between the first century BC and second century AD. The Kuninda are sometimes described as a tribal group, or Janapada, and are referred to as a people in Indian and Western texts. They lived in the region encompassing the tributaries of the Indus and Ganges rivers though little is known about their political or cultural history.

Label: Kushan
Scope note: 1stC AD to 4thC AD. Central Asian dynasty who conquered the region from Afghanistan to south of Delhi. Associated with the city of Mathura, and with the earliest depictions of the Buddha in corporeal form.

Label: Kushano-Sasanian
Scope note: c.233-370. Sasanian-appointed governors of Afghanistan who retained the title 'Kushahshah' from their predecessors, the Kushans.

Label: La Tène
Scope note: Western Europe: 450BC-43AD The term La Tène is used to describe the material culture of the latter half of the Iron Age across much of northern and western Europe, from 450BC to the Roman conquest. The name is derived from a site on Lake Neuchâtel, Switzerland, where the first 'La Tène' type objects were excavated in the late 19thC. In addition to describing a broad chronological timeframe, the term La Tène is also used to refer to certain types of object characteristic of this period, for example a La Tène sword or brooch. La Tène can be subdivided into La Tène I, II and III, or La Tène A, B, C and D. Using these subdivisions well established typologies of La Tène objects have been created. For example, the attachment of the foot to the bow on La Tène brooches follows a pattern which is consistent over time and across much of Europe. For example, the foot of a La Tène I brooch is not attached to the bow. If a brooch of this type is discovered it is an important piece of dating evidence for other types of object.

Label: La Tène D
Scope note: 120BC-20BC

Label: La Tène D2
Scope note: 80BC-20BC

Label: La Tène I
Scope note: Europe; 450-320 BC

Label: La Tène II
Scope note: Europe; 320-125 BC

Label: La Tène III
Scope note: Europe; 125 BC - AD 43

Label: Lagash II
Scope note: A term used for a dynasty of rulers of the city-state of Lagash in southern Mesopotamia who expanded their authority following the collapse of the Akkadian empire around 2190 BC. Lagash was eventually absorbed into the kingdom of the Third Dynasty of Ur after 2100 BC.

Label: Lambayeque
Scope note: The date range covered is AD 900-AD 1250. Christopher Donnan, 'Ceramics of Ancient Peru', Fowler Museum of Cultural History, University of California, Los Angeles, 1992.

Label: Lan Na
Scope note: Lan Na was a loose confederation of states located in northern Thailand. They were controlled by the Burmese between the late 16th and late 18th century. By the late 19th century central Thailand exerted more control over Lan Na, which eventually became part of the kingdom of Thailand.

Label: Lapui
Scope note: Fars, 3900BC-3400BC.

Label: Larsa Dynasty
Scope note: A term used to describe the dynasty of kings ruling the city of Larsa in the period approximately 1900 BC-1750 BC.

Label: Late Anglo-Saxon
Scope note: In the context of archaeological material the term refers to the date range circa mid-9thC to late 11thC. For numismatic material use the Broad Term Anglo-Saxon.

Label: Late Antique
Scope note: The term is traditionally used for the former territories of the Eastern Roman Empire, ie. Greece, Cyprus, eastern Balkans, parts of the Caucasus (Georgia, Armenia, etc.), Asia Minor, Levant, Egypt and parts of Italy, for the 6thC and 7thC AD. For the 4th and 5thC AD, the term Late Roman is preferred. The term ‘Byzantine’ can be used as an alternative . The term ‘Late Antique’ is not used for the material culture of the former territories of the western Roman empire, ie. Italy, Gaul, Hispania, Britannia and Western North Africa (Mauritania, Tripolitania), for the 6th and 7thC AD. Instead, the term Early Medieval is preferred. Neither is 'Lare Antique' used for the broadly contemporary Sasanian Empire to the East (for which 'Sasanian' is preferred) or 'Early Islamic' and its Narrow Terms. For non-Roman material (post AD 410) from Britain, the terms 'Sub-Roman' or 'Early Medieval' are used in preference to 'Late Antique'. N.B. The Department of Greek and Roman Antiquities does not use the term 'Late Antique', see instead the terms 'Roman' and 'Late Roman'.

Label: Late Babylonian
Scope note: Late Babylonian is to be used for all material from Babylonia in the first millennium BC which cannot be assigned to a specific dynasty.

Label: Late Bronze Age
Scope note: Late Bronze Age is a cultural term widely used from Europe to the Far East, and is subject to local regional subdivisions with their own chronologies. Britain and Ireland: c. 1300 BC - 800 BC France: c. 1300 BC - 800 BC Italy: c. 1350 BC - 975 BC Low Countries: c. 1050 BC - 800 BC Greece: the terms 'Late Cycladic', 'Late Minoan', 'Sub-Minoan', 'Mycenaean' and 'Sub- Mycenaean' are recorded for objects described as 'Late Bronze Age'.

Label: Late Bronze Age/Early Iron Age
Scope note: The transition period covering the end of the Bronze Age and the beginning of the Iron Age is not always clearly defined in material culture terms. This mainly applies to British material, for the period spanning 1000BC to 600BC.

Label: Late Chalcolithic
Scope note: In the Middle East, the term chalcolithic is used to describe the broad period between the Neolithic and the Bronze Age (c. 5000-3000 BC). The Late Chalcolithic is a specific term used in north-western Mesopotamia to describe the period spanning the end of the Ubaid and the start of the Uruk (c.4500-3500 BC).

Label: Late Christian Period
Scope note: The term covers the period in Nubia and Sudan from AD 1100-1400. It is subdivided into and earlier and later phase designated Late Christian Period I (AD 1100-1300) and Late Christian Period II (AD 1300-1400) respectively.

Label: Late Christian Period I
Scope note: The term covers the period in Nubia and Sudan from AD 1100-1300.

Label: Late Christian Period II
Scope note: The term covers the period in Nubia and Sudan from AD 1300-1400.

Label: Late Classic
Scope note: Period covering 700-900 AD.

Label: Late Corinthian
Scope note: The term only applies to pottery. According to Amyx’s chronology (1988, p. 428), based on Payne’s chronology and modified by Hopper, Dunbabin, and Coldstream, the Late Corinthian period extends from 570 to beyond 550 BC.

Label: Late Cycladic
Scope note: The Late Cycladic period (1600BC – 1060BC) refers to material produced in the Cyclades during the Aegean Late Bronze Age. As with the Late Minoan and Late Helladic periods, it is further divided into I, II and III.

Label: Late Cypriot
Scope note: 1650 BC-1050 BC The third major division of the Cypriot Bronze Age is marked by the appearance of new pottery types, such as White Slip, Base Ring and Monochrome in the North West of the island, which gradually replace older fabrics which continue in use from the Middle Bronze Age. Other important fabrics included Bichrome Wheelmade, Red Lustrous Wheelmade and various Plain and Painted Wheelmade wares; the latter are heavily influenced by imports from the Mycenaean world in particular (but also the Levant) which gradually displace the older hand-made wares by the 12th century. The period is characterised by a thriving copper extraction industry, intense commercial interchange with surrounding regions – with imports visible from all around the Eastern Mediterranean - , and the emergence of more complex forms of social organisation, which can be called towns by LCIIC and LCIIIA. Literacy is attested in the form of documents written in a script called Cypro-Minoan, which has some links with Bronze Age Crete. The last phase of the LC period, LCIII is a transitional period marked by major changes in the settlement pattern, burial practices, economy and material culture (including pottery types); the development of Proto-White Painted and Proto-Bichrome wares signal the beginning of the Iron Age in ceramic terms. The development of iron-making technology, in which Cypriot metallurgists played a leading role, develops apace at this time.

Label: Late Cypriot III
Scope note: The last phase of the Late Cypriot period, LCIII is a transitional period marked by major changes in the settlement pattern, burial practices, economy and material culture (including pottery types); the development of Proto-White Painted and Proto-Bichrome wares signal the beginning of the Iron Age in ceramic terms. The development of iron-making technology, in which Cypriot metallurgists played a leading role, develops apace at this time.

Label: Late Haftavan Period VIB
Scope note: Period at Haftavan Tepe, Iran, c.1550BC-1450BC.

Label: Late Helladic IIIC
Scope note: 1200BC-1060BC Late Helladic IIIC and Late Minoan IIIC pottery is normally divided into Early, Middle and Late. Where these classifications are used, the following dates are accepted: Early: 1200BC-1130BC Middle: 1130BC-1090BC Late: 1090BC-1060BC

Label: Late Intermediate
Scope note: The term refers to a chronological and stylistic classification applied mainly to the Andean cultural chronology in Peru.

Label: Late Islamic
Scope note: Term used to describe material culture generally dating between the 15thC-19thC.

Label: Late Kaftari
Scope note: Fars, 1800BC-1600BC.

Label: Late Medieval
Scope note: The term is used for the period from about 1050 to about 1500. N.B. For pottery of this period, the term 'Medieval' rather than 'Late Medieval' is used. For all European coins, the term 'Medieval' (rather than the Narrow terms 'Early Medieval' and 'Late Medieval') is used to cover the period c. 400 - c. 1500. For all European coins, the term 'Medieval' (rather than the Narrow Terms 'Early Medieval' and 'Late Medieval') is used as a general term for the period c. 400 to c. 1500. Other term can also be entered, such as 'Burgundian'.

Label: Late Minoan IIIC
Scope note: 1200BC-1060BC Late Minoan IIIC and Late Helladic IIIC pottery is normally divided into Early, Middle and Late. Where these classifications are used, the following dates are accepted: Early: 1200BC-1130BC Middle: 1130BC-1090BC Late: 1090BC-1060BC

Label: Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age
Scope note: The period Late Neolithic to Early Bronze Age spans 3000BC to 1600BC. It tends, however, to be applied more specifically to the period 2500BC to 2150BC, when copper and gold are in use, but before bronze. The suggestion that this might represent a Copper Age has frequently been discussed, but never widely accepted.

Label: Late Quimbaya
Scope note: The term refers to a cultural period and a style of the Quimbaya region of Colombia in the Middle Cauca valley and the Central Range in the Antioquia, Caldas, Risaralda and Quindio departments from 800 AD to 1600 AD.

Label: Late Roman
Scope note: The term is used for the material culture of the Western Roman Empire during the period from AD 293 (reforms by Diocletian) to AD 476 (the deposition of the last official western Roman emperor). For the eastern Roman empire from about the early 4thC AD see 'Late Antique' and 'Byzantine'.

Label: Late Sasanian
Scope note: 5thC-7thC AD.

Label: Late Uruk
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia dating to between 3500-3000 BC. During this period the Uruk culture spread to western Iran, Syria and southeast Anatolia.

Label: Latian
Scope note: Used with Latium as Production place.

Label: Le Dynasty
Scope note: Dynasty ruling Vietnam from 1428-1788.

Label: Liangzhu culture
Scope note: Neolithic culture circa 3300 BC-2250 BC.

Label: Lichhavi
Scope note: Ruling Dynasty of Nepal c.576-750 AD. This culture was based on the Kathmandu valley and was influenced by the Gupta culture of lowland India to the south.

Label: Lockward
Scope note: The term has been recorded in connection with objects excavated or collected by John Eric Sidney Thompson.

Label: Lohara
Scope note: Dynasty ruling in Kashmir c. AD 1003-1172.

Label: Longshan culture
Scope note: Neolithic culture circa 3000 BC-1700 BC.

Label: Lower Niger Bronze Industry
Scope note: Everything that isn't Ife, Benin etc.

Label: Lucanian Greek
Scope note: The term refers to Greek objects produced in Lucania.

Label: Lucanian local
Scope note: The term refers to objects poduced by local peoples in Lucania, in an indigenous style.

Label: Luluid dynasty
Scope note: 1234-1262 (AH 631-AH 660). Probably of Armenian origin. Badr al-Din Lulu was recognised by the Abbasid caliph as the ruler of the city of Mosul in 1234 (AH 631). He extended his authority into Ayyubid territory in the Jazira. His son's brief rule came to an end with the invasion of the region under Il-Khanid ruler Hulegu in 1260 (AH 658). Lu'lu's sons fled to the Mamluks in Egypt.

Label: Lydian
Scope note: An Iron Age culture of western Turkey named after the kingdom of Lydia (c1300-546 BC).
