At its greatest extent the kingdom covered all of western Turkey and its capital was the city of Sardis. Coins were invented in Lydia around 660 BC. In 546 BC king Cyrus II captured Sardis and Lydia became part of the Achaemenid empire. The region never regained independence and was subsequently ruled by Alexander the Great and then the Seleucid dynasty.

Label: Mac dynasty
Scope note: Vietnamese dynasty, 1527-1592

Label: Macedonian Dynasty
Scope note: Following the wars that led to the unification of Greece under Philip II of Macedon, his son Alexander III (“the Great”) began a series of campaigns eastwards in 333 BC. A series of victories over the Persians culminated in the final battle at Gaugamela in 331 BC. Already ruler over Anatolia and Egypt, he now became ruler of Babylon and went on to extend control as far east as India. Following Alexander’s death in 323 BC, nominal kingship passed to his brother Philip III, with Perdiccas -- commander of the Companion cavalry -- as regent. In 320 BC Perdiccas was assassinated and rule over Babylon was allotted to Seleucus. He was forced out by Antigonus in 316 BC, only to return triumphantly in 312 BC.

Label: Magdalenian
Scope note: Last phase of the Upper Palaeolithic, c.14,000 to 10,000 years ago.

Label: Mahdiya
Scope note: The term refers to the period between 1881 and 1898 of the Sudanese nationalist movement led by Mohamed Ahmed al-Mahdi (the Mahdi) against the Turkiya which led to the capture of Khartoum in 1885. After his death in 1885, Mohamed Ahmed is succeeded by Abdullahi ibn Mohamed (the Khalifa) who ruled until his defeat at the battle of Omdurman by General Kitchener in 1898.

Label: Majapahit
Scope note: Late medieval culture of the last pre-Islamic period of Java, named after the capital city of the same name.

Label: Majiayao culture
Scope note: Neolithic culture c BC 3800 - BC 2000.

Label: Malla
Scope note: Ruling dynasty in Nepal Valley and surrounding areas from 10th century until 1769, when the valley was conquered by the Gorkha ruler Prithvi Narayan Shah.

Label: Mamluk dynasty
Scope note: 1250-1517 (AH 648-AH 923). The Mamluks (meaning 'one possessed, slave') arose from the Turkic troops of Ayyubids of Egypt and Damascus. Two lines of Mamluk sultans are distinguished: the Bahri Mamluks and the Burji Mamluks. The Bahris were ethnically Turkic from the southern Russian steppes with a mixture of other races including Kurds and also Mongols. The Burjis were Circassians from the Christian areas of the northern Caucasus. The Mamluks continued the strongly Sunni policy of the Ayyubids with the sultans, governors and amirs founding numerous mosques, madrasas and other religious and charitable institutions in Cairo, Damascus, Aleppo and elsewhere. They saw their role as defenders of Islam against the infidel Mongols, Frankish crusaders and heterodox Muslims in the mountains of western Syria. Egypt and Syria enjoyed considerable prosperity under the Mamluks until the 15th century.

Label: Mangujakid dynasty
Scope note: 1118-1242 (AH 512-AH 640). Dynasty in northern Anatolia with centres at Erzincan, Kemakh and Divrigi. The Mangujakid's clashed with the Seljiqs of Rum and sought allies with the Byzantines.

Label: Manteño
Scope note: The term refers to a period in Ecuador, from circa 800 to circa 1530.

Label: Maritime Archaic
Scope note: 7000 BC - modern times Northern Atlantic coast between Newfoundland and Maine. Sea mammal hunting culture, winters were spent inland hunting caribou, elk etc.

Label: Matlazinca
Scope note: ETHNIC NAME.

Label: Mauryan
Scope note: The term refers to the kings of the Maurya dynasty who ruled in northern India in the late centuries BC. Their most famous member was Asoka (273-232 BC) who is renowned for the erection of pillars on which his Buddhist-inspired edicts are recorded.

Label: Medieval
Scope note: The term refers to the period from about AD 400 to about AD 1500. See also the Narrow Terms 'Early Medieval' and 'Late Medieval'. See also the terms ‘Late Roman’ or ‘Byzantine’. N.B. For all European coins, the term 'Medieval' (rather than the Narrow Terms 'Early Medieval' and 'Late Medieval') is used as a general term for the period c. 400 to c. 1500. Other term can also be entered, such as 'Burgundian'.

Label: Mesopotamian
Scope note: The term is used to describe cultures and dynasties belonging to the region of ancient Mesopotamia, a term derived from the Greek for "between the rivers" of the Tigris and Euphrates and broadly corresponding to the area covered by modern Iraq and north-east Syria.

Label: Messapian
Scope note: Used with Italy (Southern) or narrower terms as Production place.

Label: Mezcala
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place.

Label: Middle Anglo-Saxon
Scope note: In the context of archaeological material the term refers to the date range circa mid-7thC to mid-9thC. For numismatic material use the Broad Term Anglo-Saxon.

Label: Middle Assyrian
Scope note: From around 135O BC, the Assyrians expanded their territories and eventually established an empire reaching to the Euphrates in the west and parts of Babylonia in the south. By 1050 BC the territories had been reduced by attacks and rebellions to the Assyrian homeland around the cities of Ashur and Nineveh.

Label: Middle Babylonian
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia between approximately 1600 BC-1000 BC.

Label: Middle Bronze Age
Scope note: Middle Bronze Age is a cultural term widely used from Europe to the Far East, and is subject to local regional subdivisions with their own chronologies. Italy: c. 1700 BC - 1300 BC Britain and Ireland: c. 1600 BC - 1200 BC France: c. 1600 BC - 1300 BC Low Countries: c. 1800 BC - 1050 BC Greece: the terms 'Middle Cycladic', and 'Middle Helladic' and 'Middle Minoan' are used to record objects described as 'Middle Bronze Age'.

Label: Middle Corinthian
Scope note: The term only applies to pottery. According to Amyx’s chronology (1988, p. 428), based on Payne’s chronology and modified by Hopper, Dunbabin, and Coldstream, the Middle Corinthian period extends from 595/590 to 570 BC.

Label: Middle Cycladic
Scope note: The Middle Cycladic period (2000BC – 1600BC) refers to material produced in the Cyclades during the Aegean Middle Bronze Age. As with the Middle Minoan and Middle Helladic periods, it is further divided into I, II and III.

Label: Middle Cypriot
Scope note: ca. 1900 BC-1650 BC The second division of the Cypriot Bronze Age, marking an expansion in the range of pottery types (including White Painted wares which appeared at the end of the EC period), the spread of settlements all over the island (including fortified sites) and the first signs of significant overseas contacts in the form of numerous ceramic exports to surrounding regions. Many artefacts types, including metal goods, are similar to those from the EC and continue in use into the LC. The last phase of Middle Cypriot, MCIII, witnesses a major increase in the economic and cultural dynamism of the island, including the establishment of new coastal settlements.

Label: Middle Eastern periods and cultures
Scope note: See also Islamic and its Narrow Terms.

Label: Middle Elamite
Scope note: circa 1500 BC-1000 BC. Period normally divided into three phases; Middle Elamite I c.1500 BC-1400 BC, Middle Elamite II c.1400 BC-1200 BC, Middle Elamite III c.1200 BC-1100 BC.

Label: Middle Islamic
Scope note: Term used to describe material culture generally dating between the 11th-14th centuries.

Label: Middle Kaftari
Scope note: Fars, 1900BC-1800BC.

Label: Minaean
Scope note: Refers to the small trading kingdom of Ma??n (capital at Qarn?w) based in the W?d? Jawf that was of economic importance during the second half of the first millennium BC.

Label: Ming-Qing
Scope note: Period at the beginning of the Qing dynasty when rebels loyal to the old Ming dynasty resisted the new Qing emperor.

Label: Miraflores-Arenal
Scope note: The term refers to a phsase and culture, of the Formative Period, in the Guatemala Highlands.

Label: Mitannian
Scope note: The important kingdom of Mitanni flourished in the 15th and 14th centuries BC and covered parts of what are presently north-east Syria, south-east Turkey and northern Iraq. Its capital city was called Washukanni. The material culture of this period and kingdom are referred to in the archaeological literature as Mitannian.

Label: Moche
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place. The date range covered is 100 BC- AD 700. Christopher Donnan, 'Ceramics of Ancient Peru', Fowler Museum of Cultural History, University of California, Los Angeles, 1992.

Label: Mogollon
Scope note: 250BC(?) – 1450AD Southeast New Arizona, Southern New Mexico, Northern Mexico

Label: Mon Kings
Scope note: The Mon kings are associated with the kingdom of Dvaravati (AD 550-1030) in what is now Thailand.

Label: Mongol
Scope note: 1206-1370 (AH 602-AH 771). Rulers of Mongolia who conquered China, the 'Abbasid empire, the south Russian steppes and central Europe. The Mongol expansion took place under Genghis Khan in 1209 (AH 606). He took Beijing in 1215 (AH 612) thus controlling numerous commercial routes across central Asia to China. In 1220 (AH 616) Genghis Khan captured Bukhara and soon the whole of Transoxiana was part of the Mongol empire. In 1258 (AH 656) the Mongols sacked Baghdad under Hulegu grandson of Ghengis Khan and founder of the Il-Khanid dynasty (q.v.).

Label: Muisca
Scope note: The term refers to a region and a cultural tradition of Colombia in the highlands of the Eastern Range in the Cundinamarca and Boyaca departments from 600 Ad to 1600 AD.

Label: Muzaffarid dynasty
Scope note: 1314-1393 (AH 713-795). The Muzaffarids, distantly of Khurasanian Arab origin, came to power in Kirman, Fars and western Iran as the Il-Khanid empire declined.

Label: Mycenaean
Scope note: The term ‘Mycenaean' was originally used to describe Greek Bronze Age material of the period 1600BC-1060BC , following the discoveries made at the site of Mycenae by Heinrich Schliemann in the 19th century. Subsequently the term Helladic was introduced for material produced on mainland Greece during the Bronze Age, as a counterpart to Minoan and Cycladic. However, ‘Mycenaean’ continues to be used to describe Late Bronze Age Greek material culture, particularly that relating to the palatial era, when sites such as Mycenae flourished. The term 'Mycenaean' is used in preference to ‘Late Helladic’. Where a specific 'Late Helladic' sub-division term (such as 'Late Helladic I') can be defined, particularly in the case of pottery, the specific sub-division term should be used instead of 'Mycenaean'.

Label: Nabataean
Scope note: During the Hellenistic and Roman periods the Nabataeans, an Arab people, developed a thriving kingdom in Southern Jordan and North West Arabia, with its capital at Petra.

Label: Namazga II
Scope note: Term derived from Soviet excavations at the type-site of Namazga-depe in south-west Turkmenistan, and dating to ca 4000-3500 BC.

Label: Namazga III
Scope note: Term derived from Soviet excavations at the type-site of Namazga-depe in south-west Turkmenistan, and dating to ca 3500-3000 BC. Within Soviet archaeological literature, this period term is also referred as late eneolithic period.

Label: Namazga IV
Scope note: Term derived from Soviet excavations at the type-site of Namazga-depe in south-west Turkmenistan, and dating to ca 3000-2500 BC.

Label: Namazga V
Scope note: Term derived from Soviet excavations at the type-site of Namazga-depe in south-west Turkmenistan, dating to ca 2500-2200 BC.

Label: Narino
Scope note: The term refers to a region and a cultural tradition of Colombia in the highlands of the Nariño department from 600 AD to 1600 AD.

Label: Nasca
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place Nazca, and covering the period 100 BC-AD 600 (dates according to Christopher Donnan, 'Ceramics of Ancient Peru', Fowler Museum of Cultural History, University of California, Los Angeles, 1992).Moche:

Label: Nasca-Huari
Scope note: 650-850 Transitional phase between Nasca and Huari cultures.

Label: Nasrid dynasty
Scope note: 1230-1492 (AH 629-AH 897). Dynasty in Granada, last Muslim state of Spain.

Label: Natufian
Scope note: The period known as the Natufian began about 10,000 years ago when the hunting and foraging peoples of Palestine and southern Syria began domesticating cattle and sheep. They also supplemented their diet by gathering wild grains and pulses. This gradually led to village life and the cultivation of cereals referred to as the Neolithic.

Label: Nayaka
Scope note: Name for the successor kings to the Vijayanagara rulers of south India. The term literally means 'governor', and in many cases the appointees of the old dynasty became independent rulers of the different regions on the disintegration of the Vijayanagara kingdom following the battle of Talikota in 1565. The Nayaka rulers of Gingee, Madurai, Thanjavur (Tanjore) and Tirunelveli (Tinnevelly) issued coins. The Nayaka rulers of Thanjavur/Tanjore are remembered as significant patrons of temple building and of other arts.

Label: Neo-Assyrian
Scope note: Around 930 BC the Assyrians expanded their territories eventually forming an empire that reached as far as Egypt. This collapsed in 612 BC with the fall of the capital at Nineveh to the armies of the Babylonians and the Medes.

Label: Neo-Babylonian Dynasty
Scope note: Having previously been under the domination of their northerly neighbours, the Assyrians, native rule returned to Babylon in 626 BC, when Nabopolassar seized the throne. He was part of the coalition that would later destroy the Assyrian empire, and set the stage for the rise of the Babylonian empire. Perhaps the most famous king of the dynasty is his son Nebuchadnezzar, who in 598 BC captured Jerusalem and deported some of the population -- an event immortalised in the Bible. After a long and illustrious reign Nebuchadnezzar II died in 562 BC, to be followed by a series of kings with very short reigns. The empire fell in 539 BC when king Cyrus II of Persia overthrew Nabonidus, the last native ruler of Babylon.

Label: Neo-Elamite
Scope note: circa 1000 BC-539 BC. Divided into three phases Neo-Elamite I c.1000 BC-744 BC; Neo-Elamite II 743 BC-646 BC; Neo-Elamite III 646 BC-539 BC. Period ends with the conquest by Cyrus the Great.

Label: Neo-Elamite II
Scope note: circa 743 BC-646 BC.

Label: Neo-Hittite
Scope note: By 1160 BC, the Hittite Empire had collapsed following civil war and external threats. Hittite culture survived in parts of Syria such as Carchemish which had once been under their power. These so-called Neo-Hittites wrote Luwian, a language related to Hittite, using a hieroglyphic script.

Label: Neolithic/Bronze Age
Scope note: This period spans 4000BC to 800BC.

Label: Nguyen dynasty
Scope note: Vietnamese dynasty, 1802-1945.

Label: Ninevite
Scope note: The term is used to describe the cultures represented by objects discovered in a deep excavation at the site of Nineveh. The best known phase is the Ninevite 5 culture of northern Mesopotamia and north-eastern Syria.

Label: Ninevite 5
Scope note: Period within sequence excavated by Campbell-Thompson at Nineveh. Divided into incised and painted for pottery, but can be used as general chronological description c.3000-2500 B.C. for northern Mesopotamia.

Label: North Eastern British Iron Age
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 60 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Lincolnshire and parts of Yorkshire, Nottinghamshire, Leicestershire and Rutland, in which similar styled coinages are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. The earliest coins were issued anonymously; later examples carry inscriptions that are assumed to be the names of local rulers. These include VEP CORF, AVN COST, IISVPRASV, TATISOM and VOLISIOS. The ethnic or tribal identities of these issuers are unclear, but some may have belonged to the Corieltavi (formerly "Corieltauvi" or "Coritani"), who inhabited a similar area in the early Roman period. Other groups, however, may have existed in this area before AD 43.

Label: Nubia and Sudan periods and cultures
Scope note: The term covers all periods, kingdoms and cultures located in Nubia and Sudan, including Egyptian and Sudanese Nubia.

Label: Nuraghic
Scope note: 1600BC-500BC Used with Sardinia as Production place.

Label: Nuzi
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of northern Mesopotamia as represented by objects excavated at the site of Nuzi that date to approximately 1600 BC-1350 BC.

Label: Old Assyrian
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of Assyria between approximately 2000 BC-1800 BC.

Label: Old Babylonian
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia between approximately 2000 BC-1600 BC.

Label: Old Bering Sea Culture
Scope note: 500 BC-500 - Bering Strait

Label: Old Elamite
Scope note: Term used to describe period from circa 2600 BC-1500 BC in Elam. Includes the dynasty of Shimashki (c.2100 BC) and Sukkalmah period (c.1900 BC-1600 BC).

Label: Old Hittite
Scope note: The Old Hittite kingdom begins in the late sixteenth century BC when the capital became Hattusa. Hittite campaigns extended though Syria and Mesopotamia until the Hittite army ransacked Babylon in 1595 BC. Shortly after this the Hittite Kingdom was plunged into chaos and Syrian territories were was lost. The last monarch of the Old Kingdom, reigned until about 1500 BC and the following 70 years, the so-called Middle Kingdom has very sparse surviving records.

Label: Orientalising Period
Scope note: The term covers the date range: about 700BC-600BC.

Label: Oscan
Scope note: Used with Italy (Southern) or narrower terms as Production place.

Label: Ostrogothic
Scope note: The term refers to the period of domination of Italy by the Ostrogoths, a Gothic barbarian people originally from Sweden, from AD 493-AD 553 (but including several years of warfare either side of these dates). See also the terms Byzantine and Late Antique. In Spain, the Ostrogothic short lived domination began after the Battle of Vouillé in AD 507.

Label: Ottoman dynasty
Scope note: 1281-1924; Middle Eastern and European empire, centred from 1453 on Constantinople. For the period of the Bosnian garrison at Qasr Ibrim use Ottoman dynasty and a date range 1550-1811 unless a more specific date is known.

Label: PGW
Scope note: This term is based on a new type of pottery which gradually becomes popular at archaeological sites across northern India and the Ganges valley after about 1100 BC. It is sometimes assumed that this represents a new people but it more probably represents a local cultural development which marks a convenient way of defining a new period but without marking a clear break from the previous.

Label: Pachacamac
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place.

Label: Paestan
Scope note: Used with Italy or narrower terms as Production place.

Label: Pagan
Scope note: The term refers to a period of early medieval Burmese history based on the name of the capital city of Pagan (Bagan) in central Burma, 11th to 13th centuries.

Label: Pahlavi dynasty
Scope note: 1925-1979 (SH 1304-SH 1358). Iranian dynasty succeeding the Qajar dynasty. The Pahlavis under Muhammad Reza Shah gave up the throne during the Islamic Revolution of 1979. Iran became an Islamic Republic with Ayatollah Khomeini as the Head of State.

Label: Palmyrene
Scope note: Term referring to the culture of the city and oasis of Palmyra in Syria

Label: Panuco
Scope note: This refers to Gulf Coast Middle to Late Post-Classic.

Label: Parthian
Scope note: At the height of its power, the Parthian state extended far beyond the modern political borders of Iran. It was ruled by the Arsacid dynasty and its first great ruler Mithradates I defeated his Seleucid overlords in a series of campaigns in the second century BC. Their earliest capital was at Mithradatkirt (modern Nysa) in Turkmenistan but they later established their capital at Ctesiphon in what is now southern Iraq and opposite the previous Seleucid capital of Seleucia on the Tigris. Parthia fought a number of wars with the Romans and at one period held much of Syria. The end of the period is marked by the defeat of the Parthian king Artabanus IV in AD 224 by an Iranian noble called Ardashir who went on to establish the Sasanian empire.

Label: Persian Period
Scope note: This term is used in the Lachish Collection as a chronological term covering the period 539 B.C. to 331 B.C. For cuneiform tablets belonging to the same period, use the term 'Achaemenid Dynasty'.

Label: Perso-Greek
Scope note: A style resulting from the interaction of Greek and Persian craft production, primarily as a result of the Persian control of East Greek (q.v.) communities in 6th-4thC BC.

Label: Peucetian
Scope note: Used with Italy (Southern) or narrower terms as Production place.

Label: Phoenician/Punic
Scope note: Used with Africa (North) or narrower terms as Production place.

Label: Phrygian
Scope note: An Iron Age culture of west central Turkey named after the kingdom of Phrygia (c900-700 BC) with a capital at Gordion. Invasions by Cimmerians, nomads from the Ukraine and Russia, around 700BC culminated in the capture of Gordion in 696 BC, but Phrygian art and culture continued to flourish. Lydians then took over the territory in the 620s BC until the capture of Sardis by king Cyrus II in 546 BC when Lydia became part of the Achaemenid empire.

Label: Phylakopi I Culture
Scope note: The latest of the three cultural groups into which the Early Cycladic (q.v.) period is divided, based on consistently recurring types of pottery, bronze and marble objects. The name refers to the type site used by Colin Renfrew to define the culture, although the term applies to material from the Cyclades as a whole. There are not always clear boundaries between cultural groups, but an approximate date range is 2300BC – 2000BC.

Label: Picene
Scope note: Used with Picenum as Production place.

Label: Pictish
Scope note: The term refers to the culture of the Picts, a people in north-eastern Scotland mentioned in written sources from the fourth to ninth centuries AD.

Label: Post-Akkadian
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of northern Mesopotamia in the period following the collapse of the Akkadian Empire around 2150 BC.

Label: Post-Christian
Scope note: This term applies to Sudan following 14thC in the north and the 16thC in central Sudan.

Label: Post-Colony
Scope note: Term used to describe the period following the collapse of the Assyrian trade colonies in central Turkey after c. 1781 BC when Assyrian territories came under Babylonian control. During the twentieth and nineteenth centuries BC the Assyrian city-state of Assur had extensive contact with cities in central Turkey. The Assyrians established "merchant colonies" in cities such as Kanesh (modern Kültepe), which had special tax status. The trade consisted of lead or tin and textiles from Assyria, that were traded for precious metals in Anatolia.

Label: Post-Medieval
Scope note: This is a catch-all term used for post-1500 objects mainly from England.

Label: Post-Meroitic
Scope note: 4th – 6thC AD

Label: Pottery Neolithic
Scope note: The start of the Pottery Neolithic period in the Middle East is traditionally associated with the first examples of fired pottery vessels, around 7000 BC and lasts until the start of the Chalcolithic period (copper age), which varies from 6000-5000 BC depending on geographical location.

Label: Pre-Aksumite
Scope note: East African highland culture centered in modern Northern Ethiopia, before the rise of the state of Axum, from the middle of the 1st millennium BC (500BC) and possibly earlier, up to the 1st century AD. Cultural contacts are evident between the indigenous peoples and various Semitic speaking groups from southwest Arabia.

Label: Pre-Columbian
Scope note: The term is used mainly in the archaeological literature, and refers to the art and archaeology of pre-European cultures.

Label: Pre-Pottery Neolithic
Scope note: Refers to the early Neolithic period in the Levant and upper Mesopotamia. It is subdivided between the earlier Pre-Pottery Neolithic A (10,200-9,200 BP) and later Pre-Pottery Neolithic B (9,200 and 8,000 BP) following nomanclature originally devised by Kathleen M. Kenyon on thge basis of material recoverred during excavations at Jericho in the southern Levant between 1952 and 1958.

Label: Pre-Pottery Neolithic B
Scope note: The Pre-Pottery Neolithic B (PPNB) (9,200-8,000 BP) is a division of the Neolithic named by Kathleen Kenyon during her excavations at Jericho. The PPNB encompasses a major transition in the lifestyles of the inhabitants of the Mediterranean coast of the Middle East. The population increased and significant common traits within what has been termed an ‘Interaction Sphere’ include chipped stone typologies, subsistence based on cultivation and herding, rectangular architecture, the utilisation of burnt lime plaster and ritual practices focussed on skulls, symbolic statuary and baked clay figurines.

Label: Prehistoric
Scope note: Korea: C6000 BC - 2000 BC

Label: Proto-Corinthian
Scope note: 700BC-640BC Used with Corinth as Production place The term only applies to pottery.

Label: Proto-Elamite
Scope note: circa 3200 BC-3000BC. Term usually used to describe script rather than a culture within the region that was later known as Elam.

Label: Proto-Urban Period
Scope note: Term used in Palestinian archaeology, sub-divided into three phases, "Proto-Urban A" etc, dating between ca 3500-3000 BC.

Label: Ptolemaic
Scope note: This period begins from the conquest of Egypt by Alexander in 332 BC down to the Battle of Actium in 31 BC. The term Ptolemaic is frequently used by G&R for Hellenistic terracottas made in Egypt.

Label: Punic
Scope note: This term refers to the Punic, western Mediterranean culture contemporary with the Iron Age and Roman Republican period. The culture exhibits elements of Greco-Roman culture but is essentially autonomous. It refers to Carthage and its settlements established in Sardinia, Spain and Western Sicily, and also to those settlements of North Africa around Carthage. It is related to the Classical World but also to Levantine cultures as its origins are from the Phoenician settlements. This culture may thus be taken back as far as the foundation of Carthage in the 9th century (Roman sources date it to 814 BC) until its destruction by the Romans in 146 BC, but also may extend as far into the Early Modern period when it was refounded by the Romans until it was again destroyed circa AD 698.

Label: Punuk
Scope note: 500-1000 - Bering Strait Arose directly from Old Bering Sea Culture.

Label: Qajar dynasty
Scope note: The Qajars ruled from 1779 to 1924. Dynasty from Astarabad, south-east of the Caspian Sea. Under the Qajars the capital of Persia was moved to Tehran.

Label: Qaleh
Scope note: Fars, 1600BC-1350BC.

Label: Qarakhanid dynasty
Scope note: Turkic dynasty in Transoxania, Fergana and eastern Turkestan who settled in Transoxania after the decline of the Samanids and temporaily occupied Bukhara in 992 (AH 392). The river Oxus became the boundary between the Qarakhanids and the Ghaznavids.

Label: Qatabanian
Scope note: Refers to the kingdom of Qatab?n (capital at Timna?) based in the W?d? Beihan region that controlled large parts of ancient Yemen during the second half of the first millennium BC.

Label: Quang Trung
Scope note: Vietnamese reign period 1788-1792.

Label: Quimbaya
Scope note: The term refers to a region of Colombia in the Middle Cauca valley and the Central Range in the Antioquia, Caldas, Risaralda and Quindio departments from 500 BC to 1600 AD.

Label: Rajput
Scope note: Warrior ruling class. The Rajputs became important politically in the 9th-10th centuries, and for centuries they prevented complete Muslim domination of Hindu India. They eventually accepted Mughal overlordship.

Label: Rasulid dynasty
Scope note: 1229-1454 (AH 626-AH 858). Dynasty in Yemen descended from Rasul, a Turkman of Oghuz origin, employed as an envoy (rasul) by the 'Abbasid caliphs.

Label: Ratnakosin period
Scope note: Term associated with the present royal family of Thailand and their establishment of the capital at Bangkok.

Label: Recent Bronze Age
Scope note: Italy: c. 1350 BC - 1200 BC

Label: Recuay
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and style, named after the place.

Label: Restored Le dynasty
Scope note: Vietnamese dynasty, 1533-1788 state name: Dai Viet

Label: Rhodian
Scope note: Used with Rhodes as Production place.

Label: Rimac
Scope note: 900-1430, Central Coast.

Label: Roman
Scope note: See also the term 'Graeco-Roman'.

Label: Roman Imperial
Scope note: The Roman Imperial period dates from the end of the Roman Republic in 31 BC and the term is commonly used up to the fall of Rome in AD 410. For coins, the term is used for issues of the mints of the Roman Empire (as opposed to Roman Provincial, used for issues of Greek colonies during the Roman Empire).

Label: Roman Period
Scope note: This term refers to the start of the Roman rule of Egypt in 30 BC to the Islamic Conquest in AD 641. Researchers seeking Byzantine material from Egypt should search under Roman Period as well as Coptic.

Label: Roman Provincial
Scope note: The term is a numismatic term used for the local civic mints of the Roman Empire producing coinage intended for local circulation during the 1stC BC to the 3rdC AD. This distinguishes them from the coins of the official Imperial mint at Rome or its subsidiaries. For objects produced in ancient Judaea under the Hasmonean (c. 170-37BC) and Herodian (37BC-95AD) dynasties and during the two Jewish revolts (The Jewish War 66-68AD and The Bar Kochba Revolt 132-135AD), see the term 'Judaean'.

Label: Roman Republican
Scope note: The Roman Republic is traditionally said to date from the expulsion of the last King of Rome in 510 BC. The end of the Republic can be dated to the battle of Actium in 31 BC or the date when Octavian took the title of Augustus in 27 BC. The former date is generally used for coins. For material issued in areas of Italy outside Roman rule during this period see 'Italic'.

Label: Romanesque
Scope note: The term refers to a style from about 1050 to about 1200.

Label: Romano-British
Scope note: The term is used for material culture which can be assigned to Britain during the period of Roman administration, AD 43 to circa AD 410.

Label: Romano-Iberian
Scope note: This term refers to those Greek and Iberian settlements of Spain, which after the Roman conquest in the late 3rdC BC-early 2ndC BC, produced a new culture which infused elements from all of these three disparate cultural identities. This term should be used for coins minted within Spain during the period of Roman Republican control, but can also be used for other forms of material culture from the same geographic and chronological continuum.

Label: Sabaean
Scope note: Refers to the kingdom of Saba? (capital at Marib) based in the W?d? Adhana region that controlled large parts of ancient Yemen during the first half of the first millennium BC.

Label: Sadian Sharifs
Scope note: The Sharifs in Morocco claimed descent from the Prophets grandson Hasan ibn 'Ali, and the Sa'did's claimed descent through Hasan's grandson Muhammad ibn 'Abdallah called the 'Pure Soul' (al-Nafs al-Zakiyya) who was killed at Medina in 767 (AH 145). The Sa'did's ruled in the 16th and mid 17th centuries.

Label: Safavid dynasty
Scope note: 1501-1722 (AH 907-AH 1135). The family traced its ancestry to Shaykh Safi al-Din who died in 1334 and is buried at the shrine in Adabil in north-western Iran. In 1501 (AH 905) Isma'il defeated the Aq Qoyunlu, seized Azarbaijan and took control of the whole of Persia. He declared Twelver Shi'ism as the state religion of Iran. The Safavids traced their lineage through the seventh Imam, Musa al-Kazim to ‘Ali, the Prophet Muhammad's son in law and his family. In 1514 (AH 920) Isma'il I and his army of Turkmen Qizilbash ('red heads' because of their red caps) suffered a humiliating defeat by the Ottoman Sultan Selim I at the battle of Chaldiran in north-western Iran. His son and successor Tahmasp I was either defending his western and eastern borders or controlling the Qizilbash. The most outstanding ruler of this dynasty was Shah ‘Abbas who drove the Ottomans out of the Azabarjian and established Persian control over the Caucasus and the Persian Gulf. Isfahan became the capital of Safavid Iran. Safavid rule collapsed with the invasion of the country by the Afghan Ghilzays in 1722 (AH 1135).

Label: Saffarid dynasty
Scope note: 861-1003 (AH 247-AH 393). Dynasty in Eastern Persia. Ya'qub and his brother 'Amr derived their name from their founders trade of coppersmith (Saffar). The province of Sistan became the centre of a vast empire which covered almost all of Persia, except for the north-west and the Caspian region. The empire stretched to the frontiers of India. The Saffarids openly proclaimed their contempt for the 'Abbasids and effectively demolished the 'caliphal fiction'.

Label: Salghurid dynasty
Scope note: 1148-1282 (AH 543-AH 681). Ruled in Fars, southern Iran, as vassals of the Seljuqs and then in the 13th century as vassals of the Khwarazm Shahs and Mongols. They were of Turkmen origin. Sunqur was the founder of the Salghurids of Fars who consolidated his position in Persia when the power of the Great Seljuqs declined.

Label: Saltuqid dynasty
Scope note: The Saltuqids were a Turkmen dynasty in the 12th to early 13th centuries in eastern Anatolia (modern Turkey). They were conquered in 1202 by the Seljuqs of Rum.

Label: Samanid dynasty
Scope note: 819-1005 (AH 204-AH 395). Dynasty of local land owners in Khurasan and Transoxania who claimed descent from pre-Islamic Sasanian emperors of Iran. New Persian language and literature flourished under Samanid rule. In the middle of the 10th century a series of revolts resulted in decentralisation and enabled the Qarakhanids and Ghaznavids to cease control over Samanid territories in 1005 (AH 395).

Label: Samarran
Scope note: This term is restricted to Mesopotamian archaeology, specifically for a prehistoric culture dating to 6500BC-6000BC. It is named after the site where it was first recognised - see also Samarra as a site name. In the case of the early Islamic material, the Material Culture is usually Abbasid.

Label: Samnite
Scope note: Used with Italy or narrower terms as Production place.

Label: San Agustin
Scope note: The terms refer to a region and a cultural tradition of Colombia in the upper Magdalena valley in the Huila department from 1000 BC to 1600 AD.

Label: San Agustin Regional Classic
Scope note: The terms refer to a period of the San Agustin cultural tradition of Colombia in the upper Magdalena valley in the Huila department from 1 AD to 900 AD.

Label: Sasanian
Scope note: 3rdC-7thC AD.

Label: Scythian
Scope note: Originally a nomadic people, thought to be of Iranian origin, who moved into the Ukrainian/south Russian steppes around the 7th century BC. They were finally driven out by the Sarmatians in the 2nd century BC.

Label: Seleucid
Scope note: Use Seleucid Dynasty (or Macedonian Dynasty if appropriate) for cuneiform tablets.

Label: Seleucid Dynasty
Scope note: This dynasty takes its name from Seleucus, one of Alexander the Great’s generals. He first came to power in Babylon in 320 BC. Having been forced out in 316 BC, he returned in 312 BC. Babylonian tablets date the first full year of Seleucus’ rule at 311 BC. His reign marks the beginning of the Seleucid Era, according to which all subsequent years would now be counted from a fixed point, rather than simply counting the years of a particular king’s rule.

Label: Seljuq dynasty
Scope note: 1040-1194 (AH 431-AH 590). Turkic dynasty ruling in Persia, Iraq and Syria that reunited central 'Abbasid lands. The Seljuqs had originally their home in the steppes north of the Caspian and Aral Seas. They converted to Islam at the end of the 10th century. Under Toghril I Beg they seized Nishapur, the capital of the Ghaznavids in 1038 (AH 429). He entered Baghdad in 1055 (AH 447) and had his title of sultan confirmed by the caliph. The sultanate of the Great Seljuqs was based on a hierarchically organised state in the Perso-Islamic monarchic system, with the supreme sultan supported by a Perian and Arab beaurocracy and a multi-national army directed by Turkish slave commanders. Under Alp Arslan and his son Malik Shah the Great Seljuq empire reached its zenith and Isfahan was the capital. The Seljuqs founded various orthodox Sunni madrasas or religious colleges in Irag and the Persian lands and encouraged a synthesis of traditional theological and legal studies with the spirit of Sufism.

Label: Seljuqs of Rum
Scope note: 1081-1307 (AH 473-AH 707). Turkic dynasty which originated in west-central Anatolia with capital at Konya but later spread over most of Anatolia except the western fringes. The Seljuqs of Rum were an offshoot of the Great Seljuqs. After Alp Arslan's victory over the Byzantines, one of the descendants of one of the sons established a local Seljuq sultanate in Anatolia. The Latin conquest of Constantinople in 1204 (AH 600) gave the Seljuqs and oppurtunity to reestablish their power and extend their influence to the Mediterranean. With this and control over northern coastlands a flourishing transit trade developed between Egypt and the eastern Mediterranean across Anatolia to the Black Sea, the Crimea and the lands of the Mongol Golden Hoard. After circa 1225 commercial relations began with Italian trading cities.

Label: Serrania de San Jacinto
Scope note: The term refers to a region, a style and a period of Colombia in the Serrania de San Jacinto in the Zenu area in the Caribbean lowlands from 900 AD to 1600 AD.

Label: Shah Dynasty
Scope note: Nepalese dynasty founded by Prithvi Narayan Shah in 1768 after the final conquest of the Kathmandu Valley.

Label: Shahi
Scope note: Dynasty known as Turki Shahi, ruling from Kabul and established as far as Punjab and Kashmir, circa 750 - 850 AD. Became known as Hindu Shahi after they moved capital to Ohind on Indus river in the North-West Froniter (Pakistan) following the capture of Kabul by Arab general Ya'qub b. Layth in 871 AD. On coins they used the titles Spalapati Deva, Samanta Deva and Vakka Deva. Overthrown by Mahmud of Ghazna [q.v.] in a series of campaigns between 1018 and 1026.

Label: Shamsabad
Scope note: Fars, 4800BC-4500BC.

Label: Shang dynasty
Scope note: circa.1500 BC-circa 1050 BC

Label: Shaybanid dynasty
Scope note: 1500-1599 (AH 906-AH 1007). Dynasty of Mongol origin who came to be known as the Shaybanids or Shibanids. They moved into Transoxiana where the members of the clan acquired the name of Ozbeg (or Uzbeg) thus becoming the greater part of the inhabitant of the present day Uzbek Republic.

Label: Sicilian
Scope note: The term refers to Greek objects produced in Sicily.

Label: Sikh
Scope note: Adherent of Sikhism, a religion based on the teachings of Guru Nanak (1469-1539) and nine successive gurus. Under Ranjit Singh (reg. 1799-1839), the Sikhs created an independent kingdom in the Punjab (1799-1849).

Label: Sikh Misal
Scope note: The term refers to independent Sikh groups ruling in loosely defined areas of north-west India between the reigns of Banda Bahadur and Ranjit Singh. It is the Sikh name for the period before Ranjit Singh came to power in 1799. Sikh coins were issued by the temples (e.g. Amritsar Golden Temple), not by the rulers, from 1765 to1800.

Label: Six Dynasties
Scope note: The Six Dynasties with legitimate lineage (220-589) includes those kingdoms considered the legitimate successors of the Han Dynasty. The Six Dynasties with the capital at Jiankang (222-589) include the Wu Kingdom but not the Wei Kingdom.

Label: Sogdian
Scope note: Central Asian people of Sogdiana or Sogdia, centred on the fertile Zeravsham valley around Samarqand in Uzbekistan. It was a province of the Achaemenids (q.v.), invaded by Alexander the Great (q.v.), and was part of the Bactrian Greek kingdom until the Sogdians appear to have broken away c.200 BC and begun minting their own coins. The region was subsequently invaded by the Indo-Scythian (q.v.) and Yuezhi (q.v.) nomadic tribes in the 2nd century BC, but nevertheless remained a prosperous centre until the Mongol (q.v.) invasions in the early 13th century. The Sogdians occupied a key position along the ancient Silk Road and, from the early 3rd century BC until the 10th century AD, played a major role in facilitating trade between China and Central Asia. They were the dominant merchants, their language became the lingua franca of the Silk Road, and they played an important role not only in trade but also in the spread of philosophies and religions, such as Manichaeism and Buddhism, to the east.

Label: Solutrean
Scope note: In the Upper Palaeolithic, c.18000 - 14000 years ago.

Label: Sonso
Scope note: The term refers to a period and a culture of the Calima region of Colombia in the Western Range of the Valle del Cauca department from 700 AD to 1600 AD.

Label: South Western British Iron Age
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 80 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Dorset, parts of Somerset, Wiltshire, Hampshire and the Isle of Wight, in which similar styled coins are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. The ethnic or tribal identities of the issuers of South Western coinage - which is entirely uninscribed - are unknown, but they are often associated with the Durotriges, who are known to have inhabited this region during the early Roman period.

Label: Southern British Iron Age
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 80 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Hampshire and West Sussex, parts of Kent, East Sussex, Surrey, Berkshire and Wiltshire, in which similar styled coins are found. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. Notable rulers in this area include Commios, Tincomarus, Eppillus, Verica and Epaticcus. The ethnic or tribal identities of these rulers and the anonymous issuers of earlier coins remain unclear, but they may have belonged to the Atrebates, Regni (or Regini) or Belgae (all attested districts of the later Roman province). J Creighton, Coins and Power in Iron Age Britain, Cambridge (CUP) 2000.

Label: Su'lukid
Scope note: Minor Iranian family that briefly held control of Rayy (Muhammadiyya, al-) and minted coins there.

Label: Sub-Roman
Scope note: The term refers to cultures in western Europe following a Roman tradition after the end of Roman administration.

Label: Sulayhid dynasty
Scope note: 1047-1138 (AH 439-AH 532). Ima'ili dynasty in the Yemen and vassals of the Fatimids of Egypt who defeated the Abasyian slave dynasty of the Najahids of Tihama and by 1063 (AH 455 had captured San'a from the Zaydi Imams.

Label: Sumerian
Scope note: Sumerian is not used as a period culture term but as a language (see inscription field), instead see narrower terms. The period from circa 3000 BC-2350 BC in southern Mesopotamia is sub-divided into three main phases known as Early Dynastic I, II & III. Part of this region at this period corresponds to the ancient region of Sumer hence the assumption that all of the material culture is Sumerian.

Label: Susa I
Scope note: Khuzestan, ca 4200BC-3700BC.

Label: Susa II
Scope note: Khuzestan, ca 3500BC-3100BC.

Label: Susa III
Scope note: Khuzestan, ca 3100BC-2700BC.

Label: Susa IV
Scope note: Khuzestan ca 2700BC-2100BC.

Label: Tahirid dynasty
Scope note: 821-875 (AH 205-AH 261). Governors of Khurasan, and in Baghdad and Iraq. The family receives its name from Tahir ibn al-Husain who was probably of Persian origin. He rose to favour under the caliph al-Ma'mun and after the fall of Baghdad became the governor that city and Jazira. He as then appointed Governor of the East. The Tahirid's had great wealth and estates in Baghdad and were renownd as patrons of Arabic culture.

Label: Taino
Scope note: The term refers to a culture and a style.

Label: Tairona
Scope note: The term refers to a region and a cultural tradition of Colombia in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta and the Caribbean Coast in the Magdalena department from 200 AD to 1600 AD.

Label: Tairona Period
Scope note: The term refers to a period in the Tairona cultural tradition of Colombia in the Sierra Nevada de Santa Marta and the Caribbean Coast in the Magdalena department from 900 AD to 1600 AD.

Label: Taizu Guangshun
Scope note: 951-954 (reign); Emperor Taizu.

Label: Talamancan
Scope note: The term has been used with reference to pottery from Panama.

Label: Tanque Verde
Scope note: It has not been possible to verify this term, which was recorded in connection with pottery sherds from Trinidad.

Label: Tay Son dynasty
Scope note: Vietnamese reign period 1777-1802

Label: Teotihuacan
Scope note: The term applies to objects made in the style of, and under the sphere of influence of, the city of Teotihuacan, dated c. 100 BC - AD 750.

Label: Terminal Christian Period
Scope note: The term covers the period in Nubia and Sudan from AD 1400-1500.

Label: Thai Binh reign period
Scope note: Thai Binh reign period (970-979; 979-980)

Label: Thai Duc
Scope note: Vietnamese reign period 1776-1793

Label: Thien Hung reign period
Scope note: Thien Hung reign period (1459-1460).

Label: Thien Phuc reign period
Scope note: Thien Phuc reign period (980-988)

Label: Thieu Binh reign period
Scope note: Thieu Binh reign period (1434-1440)

Label: Third Dynasty of Ur
Scope note: With his capital at Ur, Ur-Nammu established his control over southern Mesopotamia around 2100 BC. Ur-Nammu and his descendants ruled until approximately 2000 BC when the kingdom collapsed owing to invasion and rebellion.

Label: Three Kingdoms Korea
Scope note: In traditional historiography, the term 'Three Kingdoms' refers to Silla, Koguryo and Paekche. Kaya was a confederacy, and although contemporary with the others, was not regarded a a kingdom.

Label: Thuan Thien reign period
Scope note: Thuan Thien reign period (1428-1433).

Label: Thule
Scope note: 1000 - Historic period Arising from Birnirk Culture on the North Alaskan coast spreading eastwards along the Arctic coast to Greenland. Eventually incorporating the Dorset Culture.

Label: Timurid dynasty
Scope note: 1370-1507 (AH 7721-AH 913). Dynasty named after Timur Lang (Tamerlain) who came from the Barlas clan of Turkicised Mongols. Timur acquired the title guregen/kureken, Mongolian for 'royal son-in-law' because of his marriage to a Chingizid princess. Timur was interested in settled lands of ancient Islamic or Indian culture and eventually built his capital at Samarkand (modern Uzbekistan). His rise to power began in Transoxiana. The later Timurids were mere local rulers in Khurasan and Transoxiana. The Timurid period was one of the most glorious periods in Medieval Islamic art in Transoxiana and Persia.

Label: Tolima
Scope note: The term refers to a region of Colombia in the Magdalena valley in the Tolima and Huila departments from 1 AD to 1600 AD.

Label: Tomara dynasty
Scope note: Rajput dynasty of northern India who founded Delhi as their capital in the 10th century. They were conquered by the Chauhan ruler Vigraharaja IV (q.v) c. 1152, but continued to rule Delhi, possibly as Chauhan feudatories until c. 1167.

Label: Traikutaka dynasty
Scope note: Successors to the Western Satraps in part of Gujarat. The dynasty is only known from coins and a few dated inscriptions ranging between AD 388 to AD 480.

Label: Transitional
Scope note: The term is restricted to the Department of Ancient Egypt and Sudan.

Label: Transitional Corinthian
Scope note: Used with Corinth as Production place The term only applies to pottery.

Label: Troy II
Scope note: circa 2500BC-2000BC.

Label: Troy III
Scope note: circa 2250BC-2100BC.

Label: Tughluqid dynasty
Scope note: Rulers of the Delhi Sultanate 1320-1414 (AH 720-817).

Label: Tulunid dynasty
Scope note: 868-905 (AH 254-AH 292). First local dynasty of Egypt and Syria with some degree of autonomy from the Abbasid caliphate in Baghdad. Ahmad ibn Tulun was a Turkish soldier whose father had been sent as tribute fron Bukhara in the early 9th century. He first came to Egypt as deputy of the 'Abbasid governor there but then became governor himself and extended his power into Palestine and Syria. The age of the Tulunids was a golden age for Medieval Egyptian historians.

Label: Tumaco
Scope note: The term refers to a region and a cultural tradition of Colombia in the south of the Pacific coast from 700 BC to 1600 AD.

Label: Tumaco-La Tolita
Scope note: The term refers to a period of the Tumaco cultural tradition of Colombia in the south of the Pacific coast from 700 BC to 400 AD.

Label: Turkman dynasty
Scope note: See also Ethnic Name Turkmen.

Label: Tylos
Scope note: Term specifically used to describe the Hellenistc, Parthian and Sasanian periods in Bahrain and eastern Arabia more generally.

Label: Ubaid
Scope note: The Ubaid period falls within the Pottery Neolithic and Early Chalcolithic periods (c.5900-4000 BC). Ubaid culture began in southern Iraq and spread northwards to cover much of the Fertile Crescent around 4500BC.

Label: Umayyad dynasty
Scope note: 661-750 (AH 41-AH132). First Islamic dynasty of caliphs, founded by Muawiya after the murder of 'Ali. The capital of the Umayyads was Damascus and from here the caliphs ruled over vast heterogenious territories. They adopted adminstrative practices of the Greeks and the Persians, the former rulers of the conquered lands. They introduced Sasanian techniques and manners which were strengthened under the 'Abbasids. During the reign of Walid I (705-715/AH 86-AH 96) they expanded militarily. All of North Africa west of Egypt was occupied and Muslim raiders crossed the Straits of Gibraltar into Spain. Beyond the Caucasus contact was made with the Turkish Khazars. In eastern Iran Khwarazm was invaded and Transonania gradually conquered. There was opposition from native Iranian rulers and their Turkish allies. Within the heartlands the caliphs faced constant opposition of Arab tribesman of Iraq. The Umayyads saw themselves not just as successors of the Prophet but as god's own deputies hense their title Khalifat Allah meaning 'god's caliph'. After 746 (AH 128) a revoltutionary movement began in Khurasan under 'Abu Muslim and the anti Umayyad forces gained military victory. This resulted in the succession of the 'Abbasids to the caliphate in 750 (AH 132).

Label: Umayyads of Spain
Scope note: 756-1031 (AH 138-422). Revival in Spain of Umayyad rule. In 756 (AH 138) 'Abd al-Rahman I, later called al-Dakhil (the Incomer), who had escaped slaughter in the Abbasid Revolution, appeared in Spain and created the Umayyad state there.

Label: Umbrian
Scope note: Used with Umbria as Production place.

Label: Urartian
Scope note: An Iron Age culture of eastern Turkey named after the kingdom of Urartu (c 860-585 BC) centred around Lake Van. At its height, the Urartian kingdom extended north into modern Armenia and southern Georgia; west to the sources of the River Euphrates in Turkey; east to modern Lake Urmia and south to the sources of the River Tigris. Urartu passed into the hands of the Orontid kingdom of Armenia after invasions by Scythians and Medes from the areas of modern Ukraine, Russia, Kazakhstan and Iran around 612 BC.

Label: Uruk
Scope note: The term is used to describe the culture of southern Mesopotamia represented by objects excavated at the site of Uruk that date to approximately 4000 BC-3000 BC.

Label: Valdivia
Scope note: The term refers to a culture (c. 3500 BC-1500 BC); also a style named after the type site on coastal Ecuador.

Label: Veraguas
Scope note: The term refers to an archaeological style.

Label: Vicus
Scope note: The term refers to a culture (c. 1000 BC-300 AD); also a style.

Label: Vijayanagara
Scope note: This term refers to the South Indian kingdom based in the Deccan Plateau named after its capital city of Vijayanagara. It was established in 1336, rose to prominence in the region, and was eventually defeated in the early 17th century.

Label: Viking
Scope note: The term 'Viking' is used for all non-numismatic material, wherever it is produced. The terms 'Anglo-Viking' and 'Hiberno-Norse' and 'Hiberno-Viking' are restricted to coins.

Label: Vin?a
Scope note: The Vin?a culture developed throughout the central Balkans during the middle-late Neolithic (c. 5000-4000 BC). Vin?a sites are the first tells of the central Balkans, therefore they are characterised by multi-phase sequences. During the later phases simple tools and ornaments hammered from copper were made.

Label: Vuppadeva
Scope note: Dynasty ruling in Kashmir c. AD 1172-1213.

Label: Wadi Suq
Scope note: Cultural term applied to early part of the 2nd millennium BC in south-east Arabia.

Label: Western British Iron Age
Scope note: This term is restricted to Iron Age numismatics, and applies to coins produced between 50 BC-AD 50. It refers to an area roughly equivalent to modern Gloucestershire, Avon and western Oxfordshire, parts and parts of Herefordshire, Worcestershire, Warwickshire, Berkshire, Wiltshire and Somerset. The various issuing authorities of this area seem to have relied on the same sources of technology and craftsmanship. The earliest coins were issued anonymously; later examples carry inscriptions that are assumed to be the names of local rulers. These include BODVOC, CORIO, COMVX, CATTI, ANTED and EISV. The ethnic or tribal identities of these issuers are unclear, but some may have belonged to the Dobunni who inhabited a similar area in the early Roman period. Other groups, however, may have existed in this area before AD 43.

Label: Western Ganga
Scope note: Dynasty ruling southern Karnataka and part of Tamil Nadu in own name and also, in some periods, under suzerainty of other dynasties 4th-11th century.

Label: Western Ganga Dynasty
Scope note: The Western Ganga Dynasty (c. 350-1000) ruled parts of Karnataka in the Deccan.

Label: Western Greek
Scope note: The term refers to Greek objects produced in Southern Italy or Sicily. For objects produced by local peoples in these places, in an indigenous style, see: Apulian and Lucanian.

Label: Western Han dynasty
Scope note: 206 BC-9 AD

Label: Western Satraps
Scope note: Successors of the Indo-Scythians (q.v.) ruling in western and central India (modern Gujarat, southern Sindh, parts of Maharashtra, Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh) 1st-4th century AD.

Label: Western Turks
Scope note: Nomadic Turkish tribes who gained control of Afghanistan from the Huns in the 6th-7th century.

Label: Western Xia dynasty
Scope note: A kingdom in western China from 1038-1227.

Label: Woodland Period
Scope note: The term refers to a period covering 1000 BC to 1000 AD in North America.

Label: Wudi
Scope note: 140-87BC (reign)

Label: X-Group Culture
Scope note: 4th – 6thC AD

Label: Xin dynasty
Scope note: 9-23. In some sources: 9-25.

Label: Yangdi
Scope note: 605-618 reign

Label: Yangshao culture
Scope note: Neolithic culture circa 5000 BC-3000 BC.

Label: Yarmukian
Scope note: The Yarmukian Culture (5600-5000 BC) was first recognised at the site of Shaar Hagolan (Central Jordan Valley) and was named after the nearby Yarmuk River. In this period the Levant region was characterized by regional cultures and sites are distinguished by distinct forms of material culture (pottery, flint etc).

Label: Yashaskara and Parvagupta
Scope note: Dynasty ruling in Kashmir c. AD 939-1003.

Label: Yotoco
Scope note: The term refers to a period and a culture of the Calima region of Colombia in the Western Range of the Valle del Cauca department from 200 BC to 1200 AD

Label: Yuezhi
Scope note: Precursors of the Kushans. According to Chinese official histories, departed from north-west China c.175BC and arrived Bactria by c.145BC. Dominated Bactria and Kabul region and expanded into Gandhara and the Punjab under Kujula Kadphises, ending Parthian rule. Once Kujula had come to power, the Yuezhi became known as the Kushans.

Label: Zand dynasty
Scope note: The Zand dynasty ruled Persia (except Khurasan) from 1751-1794 (AH 1164-AH 1209), the first ruler Karim Khan reigned as regent (vakil) for Ismail III of the Safavids.

Label: Zangid dynasty
Scope note: 1127-1251 (AH 521-AH 649). Jazira and Syria, originally Seljuq goverors, began Muslim counter-attack against Crusader states. The end of the Zangids came with the rise of power of Badr al-Din Lu'lu who ruled in Mosul until the arrival of the Mongols under Hulegu.

Label: Zenu
Scope note: The term refers to a region and a cultural tradition of Colombia in the Caribbean lowlands from 150 BC to 1600 AD.

Label: Zhaodi
Scope note: 86-73BC (reign)

Label: Zhengde
Scope note: 1506-1521 Emperor Wuzong.

Label: Zhou dynasty
Scope note: circa 1050 BC-221 BC

Label: Ziyarid dynasty
Scope note: 931-c.1090 (AH 319-AH 413). Local dynasty in the remote highland region of Daylam at the south-west corner of the Caspian Sea. The Ziyarids descended from Mardawij ibn Ziyar of the royal clan of Gilan. His power extended as far south as Isfahan and Hamadan but he was murdered in 935 (AH 323) by his own Turkish slave troops. The Ziyarids lost their power but Mardawij's brother, Wushmgir, retained a foot hold in the eastern Caspian provinces by acknowledging as his overlords the Samanids. In the 11th century the Ziyarids has to recognise the overlordship of the Ghnazvids and survived as vassals of the Seljuqs in the highland region.
